*****************************************************

Dear Students,

The second phase of the registration process is called the
*Semester Enrollment Phase  *where you get two days to make minor changes
to your pre-registration, if any. All of you are advised to go through this
user guide which has the updated instructions for this phase. The updated
timetable
<https://drive.google.com/file/d/11gfkWe_UVyJkhpons4qPWjrnxspYZ_uN/view> is
also attached.

*Differences from Pre-registration phase*

   1.  Only minor changes to the pre-registration are expected.
   2. If you are adding a new elective course, please write to the teacher
   and get his/her consent in advance. If your registration is rejected in the
   Consent of Teacher (CoT) phase, you will end up with one course less.
   3. After the CoT phase, the registration forms will automatically go to
   your faculty advisers for their approval.
   4. If you want to drop a core course and focus on clearing your
   backlogs, please discuss that with your faculty adviser and perform
   the registration accordingly.

*New PG Students kindly note the following*

1. The Semester 1 of MSc and M.Tech is having only core courses, please
login the Fedena portal and register as per guidance given in the PDF. The
curriculum <https://iitpkd.ac.in/programs> is also available on the website.
2.  A session is arranged on how to do the semester enrollment through the
Fedena portal on Wednesday at 11 am as part of the orientation program. Any
confusion on this can be cleared during that session as well.
3. The New MS/PhD students please select the course GN9999. You can
Add/Drop courses in the next phase of course registration after deciding
the courses.

The deadline for the Semester Enrollment is *on Wednesday, 10th August
2022* .You
are requested to finish the Enrollment phase by * 7 PM , 10th August 2022,
Wednesday.*

-- 
*With Thanks and Regards*
*Academics Section*
*IIT Palakkad*

Dear Faculty Members and Department Heads,



Greetings from EXCEED 2.0!



Thank you for encouraging the participations. Please keep them coming.



This mail is a gentle reminder on the fast approaching deadline of *16th
August*.  Only 7 days are left before the registrations closes. Please
forward the contest information to your student community by circulating it
over your college platforms and over mails if you haven’t done yet. This
will help students to get exposure to real life industry challenges through
the contest.





Thank you,



*EXCEED 2.0 Organizing Committee (Wabtecexceed2.0@Wabtec.com
<Wabtecexceed2.0@Wabtec.com>)*











*From:* WABTEC EXCEED 2.0
*Sent:* Monday, August 1, 2022 11:03 AM

*Subject:* Launching Wabtec India's EXCEED 2.0 Campus Challenge 2022



[image: Fifth slide]



Dear Students and Faculty,

Wabtec Corporation is happy to launch *Pan-India 2022 Campus Challenge “
EXCEED 2.0 ”* and we invite you to be a part of this journey.



Click <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-EU_GEdxEiI> here to play the
official kickoff video by Dr. Sujatha Narayan (Regional Senior Vice
President, India)



*Contest Website*: https://wabtecexceed.hirepro.in/



This contest has been organized across campuses in India to:

   - Spread awareness of growth opportunities in Railroad Industry; this
   being one of the key sectors impacting the nation’s economy
   - Connect with the young talent that has the capability to shape
   emerging technology landscape of Railroad Industry
   - Provide a platform for expression of ideas in context of the Railroad
   industry to showcase creativity and innovation



The challenge's goal is to give the students a chance to boost their
creativity and align it with business realities. These challenges will
provide them with an exposure to a wide cross-section of on-going and
futuristic developments in the Railroad Industry, covering domains
like Mechanical,
Electrical, Software, Engines and Controls, Robotic welding, Dev-apps, etc.
The spectrum of the topics enables students from different academic
departments and across years to participate in this challenge.



*Sequence of Events: *





*Registration Link*: https://wabtecexceed.hirepro.in/registration



In case of any query please reach out to  Wabtecexceed2.0@Wabtec.com  or
Dr. Manoj Bhalerao (manoj.bhalerao@wabtec.com) or Rishabh Devagupta (
rdevagupta@Wabtec.com).



              Wishing All the Students *great learning* and *good luck* for
the contest!





Thank you,



*EXCEED 2.0 Organizing Committee (Wabtecexceed2.0@Wabtec.com
<Wabtecexceed2.0@Wabtec.com>)*

*From:* Pal, Anup Kumar
*Sent:* Monday, July 4, 2022 4:19 PM
*To:* Pal, Anup Kumar anupkumar.pal@wabtec.com
*Cc:* DEVAGUPTA, RISHABH rdevagupta@Wabtec.com; Bhalerao, Manoj

*Subject:* Wabtec India's EXCEED 2.0 Campus Challenge 2022

*Dear Students and Faculty Members,*

Greetings! Hope you all are safe and doing well.

We, Wabtec Corporation https://www.wabteccorp.com are a leading global
provider of equipment, systems, digital solutions, and value-added
services. Whether it's freight rail, transit, mining, industrial or marine,
our expertise, technologies, and people - together - are accelerating the
future of transportation.

I am pleased to invite your institute to participate in the 2nd Edition of
the Pan-India 2022 Campus Challenge *“EXCEED 2.0 – Empowering Innovation”*.
EXCEED 2.0 contest is about sharing our century-long, rail-industry focused
innovative heritage with the budding students. Provide them a forum to
contribute creative and innovative solutions for future of the Railroad
Industry and contribute in shaping the emerging technology landscape.

The projects in this contest will contribute towards the rail technology
journey, that comprises designing of autonomous, battery / hydrogen /
sustainable fuel powered locomotive with zero emissions, optimize rail
routes through deep learning to increase network velocity, develop an
intelligent & cyber-secured software platform for multimodal transportation
to integrate railways, roadways and waterways for passenger movement or
just something which will shape the future of rail industry!!

Students will interact with the technologist of the rail industry, *i.e.,*
software architects, system engineers, principal engineers, and other
technical leaders as they navigate through this contest. Winning Teams will
not only receive cash prize but will also pre-qualify for our potential
internship or final placement process for 2022-23, basis our hiring
requirements.

Tentative schedule is as follows:

   - Registration: 1st to 16th August 2022; Abstract Submission: 31st Aug
   2022
   - First Shortlist (basis abstract):15th September 2022
   - Second Shortlist: 31st October 2022
   - Grand Finale (top 10 teams) at Bangalore: 30th November 2022

The contest will be open for students across all engineering disciplines
and academic year for Bachelor’s or Masters courses. This will be in a team
format with 4 members in a team.

*We hope your institute and students would be interested to participate in
this contest. Upon your confirmation; we will share further details of the
contest. Please confirm back to us latest by 8th July 2022. *

Your point of contact from Wabtec during this entire contest will be *Dr.
Manoj Bhalerao *manoj.bhalerao@wabtec.com and *Rishabh Devagupta*
rdevagupta@Wabtec.com . *HirePro is our Partner* for this event and will
liaison with your institute from time-to-time. Kindly advise the key
contact/s from your campus to take the process forward.



With Best Regards,

Anup Kumar Pal



Director, Human Resources

Wabtec India Technology Centre, Bangalore

*****************************************************

*Correct the sentences*

1) Initially I was thinking of the steps I had went through for coming up
to such a height.

2)  The doctors did assured them that I was completely fine, that I had a
good muscle tone, a strong cry and that I was just like any other “normal
child”.

3) Yet another year, another set of students preparing for the same exam,
everyone have only one dream, IIT!

4) I still remember the day when I first got into coaching classes for
preparing for an one-day exam.

5) India has a unique education system designed to uphold its nation’s
culture, history, values, and customs.


*Answers*

1) Initially I was thinking of the steps I had *went* through *for coming *up
to such *a height.*

 Initially I was thinking of the steps I had *gone* through *to come* up to
such *heights*.

2)  The doctors *did assured* them that I was completely fine, that I had a
good muscle tone, a strong cry and that I was just like any other “normal
child”.

The doctors* [did assure]/ [assured]* them that I was completely fine, that
I had a good muscle tone, a strong cry and that I was just like any other
“normal child”.

3) Yet another year, another set of students preparing for the same exam,
everyone *have *only one dream, IIT!

Yet another year, another set of students preparing for the same exam,
everyone *having* only one dream, IIT!

The present continuous 'ing' form of the verb is used for something that is
true at the time of speaking

4) I still remember the day when I first got into coaching classes for
preparing for *an one-day* exam.

I still remember the day when I first got into coaching classes for
preparing for a one-day exam.

'an' is used with words starting with a,e,i.o,u, *provided the word has a
vowel sound. *"one" sounds like "won" (consonant sound) so it is 'a one-day'

5) India has a unique education system designed to uphold* its nation’s*
culture, history, values, and customs.

 India has a unique education system designed to uphold [its] / [the
nation’s] culture, history, values, and customs.

-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss

*****************************************************

Greetings to All,
On the auspicious occasion of "Azadi ka Amrit Mahotsav" let’s regain our
childhood memories with some exciting games on this Independence Day.
The Wellness Hub of IIT Palakkad will be conducting several fun events to
celebrate this day. They will take place after the Institute Independence
Day event at the *Nila Campus*.

The events that will be conducted are:
1) Slow Cycling Race (for boys)
2) Sack Racing (for boys)
3) Balloon Bursting Race (for boys)
4) Lemon and Spoon Race (for girls)
5) Three-legged Race (for girls)

To register for any of these events fill out this Google Form
<https://forms.gle/5t83o75AGuNkmjQX6> before 3:00 pm on 14th August 2022.

Requesting all of you to actively participate and contribute in making this
Independence Day memorable.

Alok Singh
International Kabaddi Player & SAI Gold Medalist Coach
Physical Training Instructor
Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad

> There are some points to keep in mind before filling out the form:
>
>    - Only one of the two roommates you have chosen will receive the form
>    in the mail, and that individual is the one who filled out the roommate
>    form (first column student's in the sheet linked below). The excel sheet
>    below is also attached for your reference.
>    - The form will start accepting responses at* 7 pm* on August 9th.
>    - The form will be open till *11:59 pm* on August 9th.
>    - The form will be dynamic, so the selected room choices will be
>    removed from the form.
>    - The leftover students will be allotted random rooms.
>    - *After someone fills out the form, it updates the available room
>    options in 10 seconds. Therefore, if two or more students choose the same
>    response and fill out the form, it is possible to submit a previously
>    submitted response inside the 10-second time limit.*
>    - I'll also be providing the response sheet with that form. Please
>    ensure you haven't picked an already selected room after filling out the
>    form (as mentioned above).
>    - If you have already selected a room, please fill out the form once
>    again (until you select a unique room that is unallotted to others). This
>    will be strictly on a first-come, first-served basis.
>
>
> Please feel free to get in touch with your batch reps or me directly if
> you have any questions.

For room allocation, I will be circulating a Google form today at 5 pm.
There are some points to keep in mind before filling out the form:

   - Only one of the two roommates you have chosen will receive the form in
   the mail, and that individual is the one who filled out the roommate form
   (first column student's in the sheet linked below). The excel sheet below
   is also attached for your reference.
   - The form will start accepting responses at* 7 pm* on August 9th.
   - The form will be open till *11:59 pm* on August 9th.
   - The form will be dynamic, so the selected room choices will be removed
   from the form.
   - The leftover students will be allotted random rooms.
   - *After someone fills out the form, it updates the available room
   options in 10 seconds. Therefore, if two or more students choose the same
   response and fill out the form, it is possible to submit a previously
   submitted response inside the 10-second time limit.*
   - I'll also be providing the response sheet with that form. Please
   ensure you haven't picked an already selected room after filling out the
   form (as mentioned above).
   - If you have already selected a room, please fill out the form once
   again (until you select a unique room that is unallotted to others). This
   will be strictly on a first-come, first-served basis.


Please feel free to get in touch with your batch reps or me directly if you
have any questions.

p.s some rooms are occupied by pg students and a few are occupied by
currently present B19 students.



With Regards,

Aptitude Test)
- Further shortlisted students go through 1-4 rounds of virtual technical
interviews
- Final step is a 15 minute PCCAT (Proctored Cognitive Criteria Aptitude
Test)

Trending Stories from Money Business

-----




Direct vs. Regular plan of Mutual Funds:

Every mutual fund has a Direct and Regular option. It is advisable to choose the direct option as the ongoing expense ratio is always lower than the Regular plan and this difference results in better returns compared to the Regular plan of the same mutual fund. The financial benefit of this can be massive in the long run.

Important Note on Direct Plans Vs. Regular Plans of Mutual Funds·

Under direct plans of mutual fund schemes, you invest directly with the mutual fund house. There is no intermediary/distributor involved. Hence, you save on intermediary costs. This reflects better returns as compared to regular plans of MF schemes.·

Under regular (or distributor) plans, you invest through a distributor or an intermediary. The fund house compensates the intermediary on our behalf. Thus cost (expense ratio) is higher for regular plans. Even though you don’t pay anything directly, the fund house does this. The result is higher costs (as can be seen in expense ratios) and lower returns.·

Apart from the expense part, everything else (portfolio of stocks, fund manager, etc.) is the same for direct and regular plans.· The difference in expenses (Ratio %) of both types can range from a few basis points (like 0.15%) to even more than a percent (like 1.1%). This might not seem like a large difference. But when you invest for the long term (say 15+ years), What looked like a small difference in percentage returns initially, would lead to a large difference of lacs(!) in the final corpus. This is due to the compounding of the additional percentage return you get when invested in direct plans.·

So by design, direct plans will always provide better returns than regular plans.· Therefore, it makes sense to invest in direct plans of mutual fund schemes. If you have been investing in regular plans, you can also switch your existing investments in regular plans to direct plans once the exit load period is over (typically 1 year for equity funds) and capital gains taxability becomes negligible.·

Switch from a regular plan to a direct plan of an MF scheme is considered redemption from a regular plan and fresh investment in a direct plan. Hence, exit load and capital gains liability may arise on redemption of such units in regular plans.

Moreover, your investment is a direct plan that will be subject to fresh lock-in, if applicable, and exit load period
Read More: https://www.quora.com/qemail/track_click?aoid=m4hgry8GNkK&aoty=4&aty=4&cp=0&ct=1659701969918485&et=146&id=4cd42e5517424f0a869611a15ec26b9b&notif_type=418&request_id=418&snid=40312285074&src=1&st=1659701969922320&stories=%5B(%3Cstory_types.tribe_post%3A+10%3E%2C+74330246)%2C+(%3Cstory_types.tribe_post%3A+10%3E%2C+75095017)%2C+(%3Cstory_types.tribe_post%3A+10%3E%2C+73642178)%5D&tribe_item_ids=bBLTNyIguI2%7CmFrS2UkujOQ%7C8TmMOLKCLBm&uid=Mcebbm1BPpQ&v=0

Ascending Triangle formation in KECL


Kirloskar Electric Company Ltd KECL.NSE surged 10 per cent to hit its upper circuit on 22nd Jul 2022. The stock has formed bullish continuation pattern Ascending triangle on daily interval. Closing above 31 mark may lead the good up-side movement in the prices.

Disclaimer: Here I have expressed my personal views. Before taking any investment decisions you should seek advice from an independent certified financial adviser/expert.

*****************************************************

Dear Students,

The fourth edition of the Industry-Academia conclave (IAC) is scheduled for
August 13, 2022. After a break of two years, IAC will be an in-person event
this time. Eminent personalities from both industry and academia will be
attending the conclave. We are arranging a poster presentation session
along with the conclave. This is a great opportunity for you to network and
showcase your research. We hope that you will avail of this opportunity and
make the most of it.

If you are planning to present a poster, fill up this Google Form [
https://forms.gle/qt9zkWHCduL3hAhx7] to mark your participation by July 26,
2022. The poster needs to be submitted (link is given in Form) by August
10, 2022, for printing. The poster must be of A0 size and in portrait mode.

We look forward to your active participation to make the poster session
successful.

Regards,
Yagnesh
Academic Affairs Secretary
(On behalf of the IAC Organization Committee)

random for your batches.

*****************************************************

*MS and PhD students kindly ignore this mail.*

Dear All,
Warm Greetings!
Similar to the previous semesters, for the next semester, we are planning
to have students elected Class Representatives. Interested students can
stand for the post and students of the concerned classes can elect their
CRs. Since students know their classmates after at least a semester of
studying with them together, we hope you would be able to elect those who
you feel would be able to represent your concerns.

*The number of CRs required is 2 from B.Tech for S3, S5 and 1 for S7 and 2
from Msc and 1 from M.Tech(Only Geotechnical 2021). Rest MTech departments
don't have any core courses this semester. *

Please note, that a minimum CGPA of 6 and no active backlogs are required
for a student to stand for the post. Also, the student should not have any
disciplinary action taken against them.

Interested students kindly fill out the form
<https://forms.gle/dBeBdKukudpoAiR57>.

* Deadline to fill the form: 3rd August 2022 at 12 pm.   *

*A class committee is a platform where you can directly express your
concerns to the course instructors. Hence please give this a serious
thought. If you are someone capable of presenting student concerns well, do
stand for the post and represent your class.*

*--*
*Regards,*

*Yagnesh Katragadda*
*Secretary, Academic Affairs*
*Students Affairs Council | Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad*
*Contact: +91-9908183474*
*Email: sec_acad@smail.iitpkd.ac.in <sec_acad@smail.iitpkd.ac.in>*
Website: sac.iitpkd.ac.in <https://sac.iitpkd.ac.in:8090/>


*****************************************************

<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITPKD_NL&yd_medium=IITPKDMailer&yd_campaign=SignsYouCouldBeOverwhelmed>
<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITPKD_NL&yd_medium=IITPKDMailer&yd_campaign=SignsYouCouldBeOverwhelmed>

“Ugh, these headaches just keep getting worse”, “Why do I feel like I’m all
over the place?”, “Wait, why did I come to this room? What am I forgetting?"

Do you often experience multiple feelings together and you can't control
them? If so, chances are you could be feeling overwhelmed emotionally and
it’s okay.

Since the pandemic onset, nearly *62%* of people feel overwhelmed and it
led to stress, anxiety, loss of appetite and constant worrying, as per a
2021 study.

So before that “Sigh! I feel too much at once” begins to affect your life,
how about you take a pause and check these signs?
*“I’m unable to focus”*
Lowered concentration and increased apathy can be a result of overwhelming
thoughts. This also increases the stress hormone, cortisol levels, which as
per doctors, affects memory.
*“Falling asleep is a tough task”*
A study showed that 93% of Indians suffer from sleep deprivation due to
stress. If you find yourself ruminating over thoughts during sleep time, it
can be another sign.
*“This is not how I usually behave”*
Feeling moody, irritable, and withdrawn could be a sign of you feeling
emotionally drained due to overwhelming emotions felt throughout the day,
as per experts.
*“I’m good for nothing”*
Being overly self-critical, self-judgmental and having increased negative
self-talk is a sign of internalizing the feeling of being overwhelmed as
per psychologists.
With work, family and personal needs, feeling overwhelmed can be
inevitable. But, as long as you keep a tab on signs and find the root cause
of the overwhelming emotions, prevention becomes easy.

Why not get in touch with our experts and discover more?

CONNECT WITH AN EXPERT
<https://yourdost.com/chatSession/?workgroup=demo%40workgroup.chat.yourdost.com&yd_source=IITPKD_NL&yd_medium=IITPKDMailer&yd_campaign=SignsYouCouldBeOverwhelmed>
For further queries or concerns, please reach out to us at
campus@yourdost.com. <http://campus@yourdost.com/>

*Always with you, *
*Team YourDOST*

*****************************************************

Dear Students

The Office of International Affairs, Chang Gung University, Taiwan! invites
applications

for their virtual exchange program in 2022 Fall.

These online courses offered are free of charge, and each course is worth
2~3 credits.

Students joining this virtual exchange program would NOT be counted as
1 towards
their balance and will receive an official transcript from Chang Gung
University.

The course list and course information are available* here
<https://reurl.cc/b20kZl>*.




*The deadline for application is 5 PM (Taiwan Standard Time) on August 12.*



For queries, please feel free to contact Ms. Chi-Chu song at
ccsung@mail.cgu.edu.tw.

Chi-Chu Sung

Office of International Affairs

Chang Gung University

Tel: +886-3-2118800*3345



Thank you for your attention!



Warm regards,

Kavitha

will soon start working on the UG brochure, the visual component involved
in the brochure is very significant. Thus, I request all of you to upload
the photos that you might have related to the institute, student groups,
student activities, and any such relevant aspects to the following *drive
link*
<https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1knOFo2iueJuEnJOQZsNdZKtU_P6CIF-J?usp=sharing>.
Particularly images pertaining to the last 7 to 8 months but not limited to
these. PFA the previous year's brochure for your reference. Kindly note
that selected images will be used in the brochure that will be prominently
displayed on all our media pages, as well as on the JoSAA website.

format (Student Name_Roll No) so that we can identify the students who have
uploaded the images.

*****************************************************

*Reading Comprehension*

Sniffer dog Tucker uses his nose to help researchers find out why a killer
whale population off the northwest coast of the United States is on the
decline. He searches for whale faeces floating on the surface of the water,
which are then collected for examination. He is one of the elite team of
detection dogs used by scientists studying a number of species including
right whales and killer whales.

Conservation canines are fast becoming indispensable tools for biologists
according to Aimee Hurt, associate director and co-founder of Working Dogs
for Conservation, based in Three Forks, Montana. At the time of writing, so
many new conservation dog projects have sprung up that Hurt can no longer
keep track of them all. Her organization’s dogs and their handlers are
fully booked to assist field researchers into 2012.

“Dogs have such a phenomenal sense of smell”, explained Sam Wasser,
director of the Center for Conservation Biology at the University of
Washington in Seattle. He has worked with scat-detection dogs since 1999.
Scientists have been using Conservation Canines in their research since
1999. These dogs have enabled them to non-invasively access vast amounts of
genetic and physiological information which is used to tackle conservation
problems around the world. Such information has proved vital for
determining the causes and consequences of human disturbances on wildlife
as well as the actions needed to mitigate such impacts.

The ideal detection dog is extremely energetic with an excessive play
drive. These dogs will happily work all day long, motivated by the
expectation of a ball game as a reward for sample detection. The obsessive,
high energy personalities of detection dogs also make them difficult to
maintain as pets. As a result, they frequently find themselves abandoned to
animal shelters, facing euthanasia. The program rescues these dogs and
offers them a satisfying career in conservation research.

(a) According to the text there are a few________ detection dogs like
Tucker.
1) faeces
2) scat
3) indispensable tool

(b) The ideal detection dog ________
1) is extremely energetic with an excessive play drive.
2) is abandoned in an animal shelter
3) loves ball games

(c) The dogs expect________ as a reward for their hard work.
1) a decent meal
2) a friendly human handler
3) a ball game

(d) The ________of these dogs make it difficult to keep them as pets.
1) phenomenal sense of smell
2) obsessive, high energy personalities.
3) liking for whales

(e) These dogs find career in ________
1) elite teams
2) genetic and physiological information generation
3) conservation research

(f) The word ‘euthanasia’ means ________
1) painless killing
2) youth in asia
3) inactive retirement

*Answer Key*
a)-2, b)-1, c)-3, d)-2, e)-3, f)-1

regards, Sandhya
-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

typo correction:
(e) These dogs find a career in ________

*****************************************************

Listen to this audio module
<https://www.bbc.co.uk/learningenglish/oromo/features/6-minute-english_2022/ep-220721>
and
answer the short questions that follow:

1) The audio mentions "Steven Spielberg’s infamous horror movie". Something
is infamous when
a) it is inside a building but famous
b) it is the opposite of famous
c) it is famous for being bad

2) "a taste for revenge" means
a) a salty taste
b) a bitter taste
c) a tendency to take revenge

3) Which of the following can be described as "notorious"
a) a drug dealer known for killing other gang leaders
b) a river that is too wide
c) a student who studies very hard

4) 'Nothing could be further from the truth' would be an appropriate
response to a comment about
a) how poor the Ambani's are
b) how common paddy fields are in Kerala are
c) how misplaced the attention to Climate Change is

5) One meaning of 'flexible' is : able to bend or move easily without
breaking. The other is 'something that can be changed easily'. Which of the
following is *not an example* of the second meaning?
a) flexible working hours
b) a dancer or gymnast
c) a person's willingness to modify their schedule

Answer Key
1-c, 2-c, 3-a, 4-a, 5-b

regards, Sandhya

-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

Dear All,

            As you are aware there has been a new parking area created in
the permanent campus (as soon as you enter through the gate on your left)
and therefore to effectively utilise the parking spaces available in both
the Nila and Permanent Campus and to maintain orderly parking, the
following regulations are now put in place.

1. All students and visitors must necessarily park their vehicles in the
parking lot in the permanent campus. *No vehicles from students/visitors
will be permitted to park in the Nila campus*, although visitors' vehicles
are allowed entry into Nila campus strictly for pick-up/drop of guests.

2. Faculty and staff members are required to park their vehicles at Nila
campus only in the four designated parking lots (opposite Samgatha, near
Bhagyashree, opposite Tilang and near Shikharam). *No parking is allowed in
front of Manogatha and Kaapi buildings *or any other buildings within the
campus.

3. Any faculty/staff member *who is unable to get a parking space in Nila
campus must park their vehicles in the parking area at the permanent campus*.


Kindly follow the regulations and co-operate with the security on campus to
ensure that there are no untoward incidents. These regulations will be in
force with effect from *August 8, 2022 (Monday)*.

=================
Regards,

Ganesh Natarajan,
Registrar I/C
Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad
04923 - 226 520
Ahalia Integrated Campus, Kozhippara
Palakkad - 678 557, Kerala.
registrar@iitpkd.ac.in
www.iitpkd.ac.in

On Tue, Aug 2, 2022 at 9:05 PM Head, Dept. of Physics IIT Palakkad <
hodph@iitpkd.ac.in> wrote:

> Dear All,
>
> Dr P Muhammed Shafi, Assistant Professor, Department of Physics, VIT-AP,
> will give a talk (online) on 04 August 2022 at 2:00 p.m. All are cordially
> invited to the talk. The Zoom meeting link and the title and abstract are
> given below:
>
> *Zoom Meeting Link: *
>
> Topic: Research Talks
> Time: This is a recurring meeting Meet anytime
>
> Join Zoom Meeting
> https://zoom.us/j/99984307763
>
> Meeting ID: 999 8430 7763
> Passcode: 112358

>
> *Title*: Sr-and Fe-substituted LaMnO3 Perovskite: Fundamental insight and
> possible use in asymmetric hybrid supercapacitor
>
> *Abstract*: The symmetry or structural stability of ABO3-type perovskite
> oxides depends largely on the size of ‘A’ and ‘B’ cations, which determines
> the material properties. The partial substitution of these cations may be
> used to tune these properties. The ionic sizes and valence states of the
> cations play an important role in improving the properties of perovskite.
> Particularly, the substitution of La3+ with Sr2+ with a larger ionic radius
> and Mn3+ with Fe3+ with a similar ionic radius favored both the crystal
> symmetry and the mixed ionic-electronic conductivity of the perovskite.
> Electrodes based on La0.7Sr0.3Mn0.5Fe0.5O3 (LSMFO55) exhibited a faradaic
> behavior with a specific capacity of 330 C g-1(92 mAh.g-1) at 12C rate,
> while this electrode maintained a capacity of 259 C g-1 at 240C (charge or
> discharge in 15s).  Additionally, exohedral carbon nano-onions (CNO) were
>  introduced as a negative electrode to design an asymmetric hybrid
> supercapacitor (AHS) with a widened cell voltage. The use of CNO as a
> negative electrode in the AHS improved the rate capability drastically
> compared to the use of rGO. This device maintained a good energy density
> even at an extra-high charging rate (600C) owing to its outstanding rate
> capability. The high-rate performance of the LSMFO55//CNO AHS can be
> elucidated by successful fabrication with a mixed ionic-electronic
> conductive positive electrode and a CNO negative electrode. Tuning the
> electronic and ionic conductivities by cationic substitution and the
> introduction of CNO negative electrodes can provide a practical high-rate
> hybrid device using various perovskites.
>
>
>
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> Dr Jayakumar Balakrishnan
> Assistant Professor (Physics) and
> Head (Department of Physics)
> Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad

*****************************************************

Dear All,

Dr P Muhammed Shafi, Assistant Professor, Department of Physics, VIT-AP,
will give a talk (online) on 04 August 2022 at 2:00 p.m. All are cordially
invited to the talk. The Zoom meeting link and the title and abstract are
given below:

*Zoom Meeting Link: *

Topic: Research Talks
Time: This is a recurring meeting Meet anytime

Join Zoom Meeting
https://zoom.us/j/99984307763

Meeting ID: 999 8430 7763
Passcode: 112358
------------------------------------------------

*Title*: Sr-and Fe-substituted LaMnO3 Perovskite: Fundamental insight and
possible use in asymmetric hybrid supercapacitor

*Abstract*: The symmetry or structural stability of ABO3-type perovskite
oxides depends largely on the size of ‘A’ and ‘B’ cations, which determines
the material properties. The partial substitution of these cations may be
used to tune these properties. The ionic sizes and valence states of the
cations play an important role in improving the properties of perovskite.
Particularly, the substitution of La3+ with Sr2+ with a larger ionic radius
and Mn3+ with Fe3+ with a similar ionic radius favored both the crystal
symmetry and the mixed ionic-electronic conductivity of the perovskite.
Electrodes based on La0.7Sr0.3Mn0.5Fe0.5O3 (LSMFO55) exhibited a faradaic
behavior with a specific capacity of 330 C g-1(92 mAh.g-1) at 12C rate,
while this electrode maintained a capacity of 259 C g-1 at 240C (charge or
discharge in 15s).  Additionally, exohedral carbon nano-onions (CNO)
were  introduced
as a negative electrode to design an asymmetric hybrid supercapacitor (AHS)
with a widened cell voltage. The use of CNO as a negative electrode in the
AHS improved the rate capability drastically compared to the use of rGO.
This device maintained a good energy density even at an extra-high charging
rate (600C) owing to its outstanding rate capability. The high-rate
performance of the LSMFO55//CNO AHS can be elucidated by successful
fabrication with a mixed ionic-electronic conductive positive electrode and
a CNO negative electrode. Tuning the electronic and ionic conductivities by
cationic substitution and the introduction of CNO negative electrodes can
provide a practical high-rate hybrid device using various perovskites.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dr Jayakumar Balakrishnan
Assistant Professor (Physics) and
Head (Department of Physics)
Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad
Nila Campus, Pudussery West,
Kanjikode P O , Palakkad -678623
Kerala , India
<hodph@iitpkd.ac.in>

*****************************************************

Greetings from IAC!
     As you all might be aware, after two long years of the pandemic, we
are finally back to the first ever offline IAC event post-pandemic. We
proudly take this opportunity to release the official merchandise for IAC
4.0 in association with *Stubborn Factory. *

We have planned for the following:
1. Round Necked T-shirt: *Rs. 330/-*
2. Collared T-shirt:* Rs. 400/-*

The designs of the T-shirts are attached herewith for your reference

Round Neck:
[image: unnamed.png] [image: unnamed.png]
[image: unnamed.png]     [image: unnamed.png]

*Collared:*
[image: unnamed.png] [image: unnamed.png]
[image: unnamed.png]        [image: unnamed.png]

We request everyone to place their order through this form
<https://forms.gle/Lit5jzLAYBcXuqgw7> by *31st July 2022. You are requested
to make the payment by scanning the below QR code only.*
[image:
Screenshot_2022-07-28-22-05-37-52_4336b74596784d9a2aa81f87c2016f50.jpg]

giving them to you in person back on campus.

Competition (eYRC 2022-23)* is in its 11th year of glory and registrations
are now open.

*Early-Bird

students:*

In the e-Yantra competition, students *learn by competing and competing
whilst learning*. The benefits to your institute are:

   1. We have a fantastic track record of students *getting placed in dream
   jobs* and companies after their eYRC experience.

   college*. The more registrations, the stronger the community.
   3. Our competition imparts Practical Skills, Knowledge in Simulation,
   Designing, Programming, Embedded Systems and Robotics - All in a practical
   manner, thus *complementing the theory curriculum.*

helpdesk@e-yantra.org.

*****************************************************

Dear All,

On August 6, 2022, Zoom will be retiring Zoom Client versions below 5.3.0
for Zoom Client for Meetings, Zoom Rooms, Zoom Phone, and SDK (5.4.0)  to
address a critical security vulnerability.

*Some of our users  are using client versions below 5.3.0, and those need
to be updated by August 6, 2022. Any Zoom clients that have not been
updated by August 6 will not be able to join meetings via the Zoom Client
for Meetings and will be prompted to update or join from a Web browser. *

To take advantage of all the latest security and functionality features of
Zoom, we always recommend updating users to the latest version, which is
currently 5.11.3.

Thanks
With regards,
Biju

*Listen and learn!*

Today's module is on pandemics and you can listen to it here
<https://www.bbc.co.uk/learningenglish/oromo/features/6-minute-english_2022/ep-220804>

*Use the vocabulary introduced to complete the sentences that follow*:
ie:

a) eradicate
completely destroy or get rid of something such as a social problem or
disease

b) declare victory
announce something to be finished before it actually is but when it seems
‘good enough’

c) prematurely
happening too soon, before the best time to do it

d) bury your head in the sand
deliberately refuse to accept the truth about something you find unpleasant

e) death sentence
the punishment of death for committing a crime, or from a disease which has
no cure

f) chronic
lasting for a long time

1) A middle-income country like India is also keen to
.......................... on Covid, thanks to the mandatory and efficient
vaccination programme.

2) When a baby is born............................... it means there has
not been a full-term or nine-month long pregnancy.

3) The phrase.................................... is supposed to be
inspired by the ostrich.

4) Do you think we will .........................poverty, achieving basic
standards of nutrition, health and shelter for all the people in the world,
in the near future?

5) Discussions are on for whether the
....................................... ought to be done away with, even
for the most heinous crimes

6) Susheela has had.........................colds since she was a child.

*Answer Key*

1)-b, 2)-c, 3)-d, 4)-a, 5)-e, 6)-f

English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

*Countable and Uncountable Nouns Quiz*

1. Countable nouns are always things that you can
a) touch
b) count
c) see

2. We use "the" with plural countable nouns
a) always
b) never
c) sometimes

3. The nouns hair, noise and time are
a) countable
b) uncountable
c) both

4. "I've got _______ money." Which term does not fit?
a)  some
b) a little
c) a

5. Another term for "uncountable noun" is
a)  plural noun
b) mass noun
c) countless noun

6. The words tip, book and job are all
a) countable
b) uncountable
c) both

7. "There's too much noise in here." In this sentence, "noise" is
a)  countable
b) uncountable
c) plural

8. Where are you most likely to notice the noun "drink" in its countable
form?
a)  in a restaurant
b) in a supermarket
c) in an article

9. When used with uncountable nouns, the words slice, cup and drop are
a) partial words
b) measure words
c) quality words

10. A single unit of rice is known as a
a)  gram
b) grain
c) drop

*Answers*
1. count
2. sometimes
3. both (see note)
4. a
5. mass noun
6. countable
7. uncountable
8. in a restaurant
9. measure words
10. grain


Note:
Can we use hairs?
We can use both hair and hairs but *in certain contexts.* Using either word
correctly is the important thing

When you want to use hairs, you should be talking about
* individual strands of hair.*
Here are some of the examples:
The tea they served me at the new canteen had 3 grey hairs in it.
(Individual strands)
His white hairs are clearly seen.

Use hair when you want to refer to *a collection of hair as a mass*. It is,
therefore, used as a collective noun here (and most commonly).

Examples:
1. I just washed my hair.
2. Your hair is looking beautiful.
3. My mother’s hair is turning white.

In the above sentences, hair is used as an uncountable collection of
strands of hair as a mass.

Similarly, 1. uncountable noun: Noise is a loud or unpleasant sound. · 2.
countable noun: A noise is a sound that someone or something makes.

When we talk about the amount of time (number of hours/days etc.) required
to complete something, time is usually uncountable.

1. How much time do we need to paint the walls? (NOT How many time do we
need…?)
2. We took quite some time to put the child to bed.
3. Hurry up – we haven’t got enough time.
4. The project was a complete waste of time and money.

When we talk about clock times, or the number of times something was done,
time is countable.

1. Five o’clock would be a great time to start.
2. I called him at various times yesterday.


regards, Sandhya

-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

A gentle reminder

Dear colleagues

Please find the details of the technical seminar. All are invited.

*Title:* Surface Analysis using X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy

*Speaker: *Dr. Pragati Chaturvedi, Molecular Spectroscopy & Surface
Analysis, Thermo Fisher Scientific India Pvt. Ltd.

*Time: *Aug 4, 2022 03:00 PM

*Meeting link:*
https://zoom.us/j/95269186301?pwd=T0s5bFExcC9YdC9KZkFwdi9QS1NGZz09
Meeting ID: 952 6918 6301
Passcode: 862594

*Abstract: *Over the past decade, improved instrument reliability and
automation have led to broader use of X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy
(XPS), changing from a specialist technique only performed by dedicated
practitioners to a routine analysis tool widespread throughout academia and
industry. This webinar provides a brief overview of the underlying theory
of XPS and demonstrates a variety of XPS experiments that can be performed
to unravel material properties. It presents some case studies of the
characterization of alloys, polymers, semiconductors, coatings, catalysts,
construction materials, etc., and insights into the technological
advancements and the many benefits it provides to the user.

*About speaker: *Dr. Pragati Chaturvedi received her Integrated PhD degree
from the Department of Physics at Indian Institute of Technology Bombay
(IITB) in 2017.Her dissertation was focused on the study of Quantum
Materials (Topological Insulator materials) for device applications. She
then joined Faculdade de Engenharia Eletrica e de Computacao (FEEC) (FEEC),
University of Campinas, Brazil as a postdoctoral researcher. Her work was
focused on Integrated Photonic devices towards technology development.
Currently she is working in the Materials and Structural Analysis Division
in the company Thermo Fisher Scientific as a Product & Application
Specialist for X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy.
regards
Dinesh

Dear Research Scholars
INYAS started the Saransh national competition last year. We received a
fairly good response from researchers across the country. The details of
the second edition is announced now. I strongly encourage you to
participate and also pass on this information to your friends in other
Institutions.
regards
Dinesh


------------------------------------------------------
Dear Ph.D. Students,
I wish to share an exciting opportunity for PhD students to showcase their
research to the society. The Indian National Young Academy of Sciences
(INYAS) is hosting the 2nd edition of "Saransh" (Thesis Competition for PhD
students 2022).
It is an attempt to bridge the gap between the budding scientists and the
community at large and provides a platform to PhD scholars across the
country to present their work to a wider audience who have little or no
knowledge in their area of research.
Participation is completely free and open to all PhD students (who have
completed at least 2 years of doctoral research) registered  in any State/
Central Institution or University (government or private) in India.
Eligibility, submission link and all other details are available at:
https://inyas.in/saransh-thesis-competition-for-phd-students-2022/
Last and final extended deadline for submissions is *25th of October
(Tuesday), 2022.*
Please encourage all eligible students to participate.
Thanking you,
With best regards,
Rajendra Dhaka
Chairperson, INYAS


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

*Indian National Young Academy of Sciences*

*Saransh – Thesis Competition for PhD students 2022*

*INYAS is pleased to announce the 2nd edition of Saransh – Thesis
Competition for PhD students. Saransh is an opportunity for the new
generation of budding Indian scientists to communicate their research to
the wider population beyond the scientific community.*

*Purpose:*

The need for scientific innovations arises from challenges faced by the
society at large. However, it is often seen that dissipation of such
knowledge to the population is laced with challenges like dearth of
appropriate platforms, lack of proper connect with audience and excessive
use of scientific jargon. “Saransh” by Indian National Young Academy of
Sciences (INYAS), is an attempt to bridge the gap between the budding
scientists and the community at large. It aims to provide a platform to PhD
scholars across the country to present their work to a wider audience who
have little or no knowledge in their area of research.



*Eligibility:*

·         The competition is open to PhD students registered in any State/
Central Institution or University in India only.

·         The student entering the competition must have completed at least
2 years of doctoral research and must not have defended his/ her thesis yet.

·         There is no entry fee.

·         Letter of endorsement for participation by PhD
Guide/Supervisor/Head (pdf file) on official letterhead is required.



*Registration and entry to the competition*

·         Registration and entry to the competition will be done through an
online application form.



*Preliminary Round:*

·         The students will submit their entries as a video presentation
uploaded on YouTube (www.youtube.com). The video must include the slides
with an embedded voice/video. Incorrect or inaccessible youtube links will
lead to disqualification.

·         The students will be allowed to present a *maximum of three
slides without any animations (any additional slides will lead to
disqualification)*.

·         Students can present either in English or Hindi.

·         Students will have to explain their thesis work to an audience
that may or may-not have any knowledge about their research area.

·         The students should communicate their work in such a way that
people can understand the real world implications of the work.

·         Analogies may help in conveying their message.

·         *Time limit: 3 minutes (exceeding the time-limit even by a second
will straight lead to disqualification without any exception).*



*Final Round (Live Online Competition through Video Conference)*

·         The YouTube entries from the Preliminary Round will be evaluated
and screened by a jury appointed by INYAS.

·         Around top ten entries in each category will be selected for the
Final round of the competition.

·         Results will be posted on INYAS website. The selected
participants will also be individually informed.

·         The final round will be conducted as an online live competition
through video conference.

·         The participants selected for the final round can edit/ modify/
change their presentation slides that were used for the first round or they
may use the same slides.

·         The presentation will be followed by a Q&A session by the jury
members.

·         The general rules for the presentation will be same as in the
first round:

o   The students will be allowed to present a *maximum of three slides
without any animations (any additional slides will lead to
disqualification).*

o   Students can present either in English or Hindi.

o   Students will have to explain their thesis work to an audience that may
or may-not have any knowledge about their research area.

o   The students should communicate their work in such a way that people
can understand the real world implications of the work.

o   *Time limit for presentation: 3 minutes (exceeding the time-limit even
by a second will straight lead to disqualification without any exception).
Q&A time will be additional.*



*General guidelines:*

·         The competition will be conducted by INYAS.

·         All submissions should be available as editable files and should
be available for later use on request.

·         The actual presentations on YouTube should have the presentation
with speaker’s video (and audio) on one corner. An example on how to do
this may be seen at:
https://www.panopto.com/blog/the-best-way-to-record-a-powerpoint-presentation/.
Please note that this link has been provided just as an example. INYAS does
not endorse this in any way. Participants are advised to choose any method
of their choice. Similar format will be required for the final round that
will be conducted on a live online platform.

·         The participant should agree to allow the usage of entry by INYAS.

·         An individual can submit only *one entry*.

·         The participant can select *only one Category *from:

1.       Category A: Physical/ Mathematical Sciences

2.       Category B: Chemical Sciences

3.       Category C: Life Sciences

4.       Category D: Engineering Sciences

·         Results will be posted on INYAS website. The winners will also be
informed individually.

·         In case of any discrepancy or ambiguity, judgment of the jury
will be final.



*Judging Criteria: *Students will be evaluated on the basis of originality
of the work presented, structuring of the presentation, presentation style
and ease of understanding for non-experts.



*Important Dates:*

·         Social media/website/email announcement and opening of
submissions: *02nd of September (Friday), 2022*

·   Last date for submission of entries: *25th of October (Tuesday), 2022*

·         Results of Preliminary Round will be announced by *15th of
November (Tuesday), 2022*

·         Final Round (tentative):* November/ December 2022*

·         Award declaration & ceremony: *December, 2022*



*Prizes:*

*Cash Prize + Certificate*

*Category*

*First Prize (INR)*

*Second Prize (INR)*

*Third Prize (INR)*

A: Physical/ Mathematical Sciences

10000

6000

4000

B: Chemical Sciences

10000

6000

4000

C: Life Sciences

10000

6000

4000

D: Engineering Sciences

10000

6000

4000

<https://groups.google.com/d/msgid/inyas/CAGTyqP%3DNaQ0SDa1ujQxZF06OE-GkPiaFP4Zec1Bo7Zg3ytANBw%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer>
.


*****************************************************

Dear Students,

 1)  Please note that in some PME courses the number of students allowed
may be restricted. This would be the case with Software Engineering,
Machine Learning, Information Retrieval and may be some other courses as
well, depending on the course instructor's decision. Keeping this in mind,
if you are not sure about the course faculty accepting your
pre-registration request, it would be wise to* pre-register for one
additional choice* *of PME and GCE*. You can drop your least preferred one
during the next phase of registration.
 2) You are not supposed to choose an elective with a significant overlap
(say more than 40%) with the content of another course which you have
credited or currently going to credit.
3) It is your responsibility to make sure that you meet the prerequisites
specified in the course syllabus.

Thanks and Regards
Jasine

Head of the Department,
Computer Science and Engineering,
Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad.


*****************************************************

Dear All,

  It is my pleasure to introduce Mr. Haragopal Mangipudi (photograph
attached) who joined our department this week, as an adjunct faculty.

Haragopal Mangipudi is a luminary in the domain of software product
management and a career software product leader specializing in software
for the banking and financial sector. He is a Fellow and a member of the
Global Board of the International Software Product Management Association
(ISPMA®), a not-for-profit global body of experts in software product
management from academia and industry. He was the chairman of ISPMA India
chapter until recently and is currently the co-chair of ISPMA North America
chapter. Haragopal is the founder of guNaka® consulting and the co-creator
of finUNO® which is a platform that delivers contextual and
hyper-personalized financial services to consumers. He was the CEO of
Finacle® and a member of the Executive Council of Infosys. He is a
distinguished alumnus of IIM Bangalore and a former member of the Governing
Board of IIM Lucknow SIDBI Centre for Innovation in Financial Inclusion.

He has an MBA from IIM Bangalore and holds Bachelors degrees in Education,
Law and Physics from Central Institution of Education (CIE), Delhi
University and Andhra Loyola College respectively.

Mr. Haragopal Mangipudi is also a member of the Institute Advisory Council
of IIT Palakkad and a member of the Hub Governing Board (HGB) of the IPTIF,
a Section 8 company set up by IIT Palakkad under the grant from National
Mission on Intelligent Cyber Physical Systems (NM-ICPS). In addition to
this, Mr. Haragopal has also been associated with the Department of
Computer Science and Engineering at IIT Palakkad as a guest faculty and has
offered a General Category Elective on Software Product Management (SPM) in
January 2022.

Hearty welcome to Mr. Haragopal Mangipudi to the institute in his
additional role as an adjunct faculty in CSE.  He is reachable by mail at
haragopal@iitpkd.ac.in

Thanks and Regards
Jasine

Head of the Department,
Computer Science and Engineering,
Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad.


*****************************************************

[image: IIT PKD Logo Strip.jpg]
<https://yourdost.com/?yd_source=IITPKD_NL&yd_medium=IITPKDMail&yd_campaign=InvestInAHobby>
Hey there!

No matter how much ever frustrating it might turn out for us to stay at
home all locked down, it is necessary for our own safety but difficult at
the same time. However, it has also opened doors to utilizing self-time,
which gets us to "hobbies- the perfect way to embrace solitude at this time!

If we were to think honestly, we would be pondered upon questions such as
why exactly have we been doing this? Or how many of us have invested our
time in something that we really love doing? Have we explored much beyond
our TV sets or our social media pages? The guilty look on our face says it
all.

But what if someone told you, that plunging into your hobby, can have an
amazing impact on your mental health.

According to the National Health Service, learning a new skill is among the
top five tips for mental well being. Having a hobby brings in a sense of
achievement and increases your sense of confidence.

Read on, your hobbies have far more positive impacts on your mind than you
know.
*1. A Happier You*

Hobbies provide you with immediate stress relief. It is the key to a longer
and happier life. Hobbies help to cut down on the stress hormone Cortisol,
which is responsible for factors like fat accumulation and hormonal
imbalance.
*2. Gets You In An Upbeat Mood*

People who actively engage in a hobby of their choice, have lower levels of
negative feelings.
*3. Improves Your Social Skills:*

Now, who would not want that. Hobbies give you something new and
interesting to talk about yourself. Investing your time in a hobby with
like-minded people will help you make more friends and ward off feelings of
social awkwardness and anxiety.
*4. Amaze People With Your Memory:*

Engaging in an activity of your choice or simply reading a book you like,
helps to protect your mind. By challenging your mind, not only you improve
your memory and problem-solving skills, but also prevent dementia in later
life.
*5. Have An Uncluttered Mind:*

Engaging in an activity of your choice helps you concentrate better.
Hobbies act as mental stimulators and in turn train your mind to
concentrate better. Hobbies improve the cognitive function of your brain.

So what's stopping you, go ahead and do what makes you happy!

We understand that it is a tough time and our experts are always here to
help you 24*7.

CONNECT TO AN EXPERT NOW
<https://yourdost.com/chatSession/?workgroup=demo%40workgroup.chat.yourdost.com&yd_source=IITPKD_NL&yd_medium=IITPKDMailer&yd_campaign=InvestInAHobby&yd_term=1>

If you have any further doubts, concerns, queries, or simply want to say
hi, drop us a mail at campus@yourdost.com.



*Standing with youTeam YourDOST*

*****************************************************

Hey guys

The first week's challenge is *DUBSMASH. *Participants have to act and lip
sync to audio of their choosing from a show, series or any iconic moment.
If the audio is from any language other than English, subtitles in English
are also required.
Breakdown for leaderboard points are:

   - 20 for every entry
   - 70 for 1st place in each round
   - 50 for 2nd place in each round
   - 40 for 3rd place in each round

We are looking forward to your entries!

*Submit them at : https://forms.gle/VyNuJtFnP5rVpDwe7
<https://forms.gle/VyNuJtFnP5rVpDwe7>*

Deadline 6/8/22

Yours sincerely
Lekshmi R Nair
Secretary, Curtain Call

Hindustan Coca Cola Beverages (HCCB) is back with this year's edition of
their flagship case competition - *HCCB Disrupt Season 1* to provide
brightest young minds an opportunity of working on one of their key
business problems, providing unique perspectives & innovative solutions.
It's an opportunity to win *Cash prizes, PPIs *and a chance to meet their
Senior Leadership team. For registration and more details on the
competition, please visit
https://www.gradpartners.in/e/HCCB-Disrupt-Season-1-38


Grad Partners <https://www.linkedin.com/company/gradpartners> will be
conducting Disrupt Quizzes from *3rd-12th August (1800-2359 hours) *on
their LinkedIn handle (https://www.linkedin.com/company/gradpartners). Icing
on the cake will be *5 winners* to be announced everyday who will get *HCCB
Gift boxes *along with a chance to get featured on our social media
handles.* Follow
our page *to participate in the quizzes starting from *3rd Aug* and win
exciting prizes!


Grad Partners will also be hosting the Launch event of the competition
on *6th Aug’22
(1700 hours onwards) *with Senior leaders of HCCB and National Winners of
HCCB Case Challenge 2021. Join the session on
https://www.instagram.com/gradpartners/ and get more insights about this
mega Business Case Challenge.

*****************************************************

Hi all,
The new cdc verification folder was created because the previous folder was
shared with every cdc coordinator but now it has been modified. Now only
cse coordinators are able to access your data. The link to the new drive is
here
<https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1AatJD6nzisPRJ0vYbColwvh0d-gQl7au>.
And don't remove the existing data in the folder which is used in
verification of the resume. Only data which is there in the folder will be
verified. Keep updating the resume until we disclose the deadline.
New drive link
<https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1AatJD6nzisPRJ0vYbColwvh0d-gQl7au>

Good day!



Regards,

Cse Placement Coordinator

Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad.


*****************************************************

Dear All,
A technical seminar as per the details mentioned below is being conducted
by the Department of Mechanical Engineering. *All are welcome to attend.*

Topic: *Micro-swimmers - Fabrication, Actuation, Sensing and Collective
Behaviour*
Date/Time: *Aug 2, 2022 (Tuesday) 11:00 AM*
Venue: Room No. *203/204, Samagatha, Nila Campus*
*Video conferencing details:*
Zoom link :
* https://zoom.us/j/93599758408?pwd=MFRQWHNMdG9NMlhjMHJ4a2lPWVlldz09
<https://zoom.us/j/93599758408?pwd=MFRQWHNMdG9NMlhjMHJ4a2lPWVlldz09>*Meeting
ID: 935 9975 8408
Passcode: 376313
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
*Abstract of the talk:*

Inspired by the mechanisms of microscopic natural systems such as bacteria
and cells, researchers in the past two decades have tried to build
synthetic devices that are able to function with the same level of complexity.
However, the conventional design and actuation principles applicable at
macroscopic scales are not directly translatable to micro and nano scales.
There are no “off-the shelf” parts that could be assembled to make a fully
functional machine that is smaller than a grain of sand. Researchers have
made intricate static structures through micro-nano fabrication techniques,
however functional dynamic machines that have been developed so far are
still elementary compared to what nature has achieved. At these small
length scales, the physical mechanisms governing motion and actuation are
different from larger length scales. This gives us an opportunity to
explore new physics and develop new technologies for powering, actuating
and sensing with dynamic small-scale devices.

In this talk, I would discuss fabrication and wireless powering of mobile
microrobots (micro swimmers) that demonstrate controllable motion in
fluids, when actuated by external light or magnetic fields or through
self-propulsion.1 I would further discuss strategies to integrate sensors
to micro-swimmers. I would then demonstrate applications of swimmer-sensor
hybrid in quantum metrology of external magnetic and temperature fields and
cancer cell targeting.2 Then, we would learn about how multiple
micro-swimmers interact with each other and collectively act in a swarm to
influence the bulk viscosity and surface tension of the swimmer-fluid
suspension.3,4 This leads to development of new materials based on
micro-swimmers, specifically an activity controlled opto-rheological
medium, whose viscosity could be reversibly changed with light.3 Finally, I
would present an alternative strategy of microscale actuation with
out-of-equilibrium fluids and  discuss nanoscale analogues of  macroscale
mechanisms.

1.*Advanced Materials.* *29*, 1701328 (2017). 2.*Advanced Materials.* *29*,
1701024 (2017). 3. *Advanced Materials* *31*, 1807382 (2019). 4.* Nature
Communications.* *11*, 2210 (2020)



*Bio of the speaker:*

Dr. Udit Choudhury is a CV Raman fellow at the Center for Nanoscience and
Engineering at IISc. He received his B.E. in Mechanical Engineering from
Jadavpur University, India, M.S. in Engineering Mechanics from Virgnia
Tech, USA and PhD from the Max Planck Institute for Intelligent Systems,
Germany and University of Groningen, Netherlands in the field of
micro-swimmers.  He has broad research interests in the field of soft
matter specializing on synthetic micro-swimmers, micro-nano fabrication,
active materials, collective behaviour, cellular biophysics, rheology and
quantum metrology

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------



--
Thanks and regards
Samarjeet Chanda

*****************************************************

Dear  Students,

Greetings!

Campus France India and French Institute in India/ Embassy of France in
India are pleased to offer a meet and chat opportunity for Indian students
with leading French institutes and universities.

This includes management and engineering schools, public universities and
specialized schools in hospitality and arts.

This is a unique opportunity for the participants to meet the schools in
person. These individual meetings will allow you to share your CV, receive
free counselling, & more information on how to apply!

Register now to be part of our upcoming “Choose France Tour” on October
11th 2022 at Kochi.

Dear All,
Please join us in welcoming our new permanent staff who have joined the
team CET recently.

*Mr. Arun M O Junior Technical Superintendent*

Arun completed his B.Tech in Information Technology from Rajagiri School of
Engineering & Technology and M.Tech in Computer Science & Engineering  from
TKM College of Engineering, Kollam. He had worked with Infosys  for nearly
2 years and for a short term of one year at Huawei Technologies India
Private Limited as Software Engineer. He had also worked as a Probationary
Officer in State Bank of India for 2 years and as an Assistant Professor in
the Division of Computer Science, School of Engineering, CUSAT for 4 years.

*Mr. Vignesh V Junior Technician*

After having completed his Diploma in Computer Hardware Engineering from
Govt. Polytechnic College Palakkad, Mr. Vignesh worked as an IT Support
Engineer at IIM Kozhikkode, Sinicon Controls Kanjikode and Travancore
Cochin Chemicals Kalamasserry Kochi prior to joining IIT Palakkad.

They will be working on both the campuses as and when required.

*****************************************************

Dear Students


 The DAAD promotes academic exchange between Germany and India, Bangladesh,
Bhutan, Nepal, and Sri Lanka. It provides information about education in
Germany, grants, and scholarships to students, invites scientists from
India to Germany and vice versa, and supports bilateral research projects.


*They are planning to organise a combined online E-Visit for all the IITs
students and scholars who wish to undertake research in Germany on
4th August at 1600 hours. The session will be for one hour. *

They would like to share information about the scholarship options at the
research level online.

The session will have a short presentation on DAAD and then a presentation
on DAAD scholarship programmes e.g., WISE, PhD, and PhD Sandwich
scholarships.


Thereafter will be a Q & A session.

Here are the links and short details to DAAD programmes mentioned,


<https://www.daad.in/en/find-funding/scholarship-database/?type=a&origin=4&subjectgroup=0&q=0&status=0&page=0&onlydaad=&language=en&id=0&pg=1&detail_to_show=57135739>*Working
Internships in Science and Engineering (WISE)*
<https://www2.daad.de/deutschland/stipendium/datenbank/en/21148-scholarship-database/?status=1&origin=4&subjectGrps=&daad=1&intention=&q=wise&page=1&detail=50015295>



For science and engineering students, who wish to do a 2 to 3 months
research internship at a publicly funded German higher education
institution or a research institute. The scholarship is open to students
from selected Indian institutions.

*Application Deadline: 15 October 2022*



*Doctoral Programmes in Germany*
<https://www2.daad.de/deutschland/stipendium/datenbank/en/21148-scholarship-database/?status=4&origin=&subjectGrps=&daad=1&intention=&q=&page=1&detail=57135739>


For young scientists and academics wishing to improve their academic
qualifications with a doctoral degree in Germany.

*Bi-nationally Supervised Doctoral Degrees*
<https://www2.daad.de/deutschland/stipendium/datenbank/en/21148-scholarship-database/?status=4&origin=&subjectGrps=&daad=1&intention=&q=&page=1&detail=57507783>


For doctoral candidates, whose doctoral degrees are supervised both by a
university teacher at the home university and an academic adviser at the
host institute in Germany
*Application Deadline: 20 October 2022*



*Scholarship database **www.funding-guide.de* <http://www.funding-guide.de>



Kindly note that the DAAD does not have any scholarships for master’s in
STEM subjects and management.


*Important:* Their target group is BTech, Integrated or Dual degree
students, Master students who are in their final year and those who are
formally registered for their PhDs at the IIT.



Please find the links.
https://dwih-newdelhi.webex.com/dwih-newdelhi/onstage/g.php?MTID=ee49dfec0f0994c0a7045cbec343e25b3
 password 4Aug.

It will not be possible to attend the session without registration. This
session is free of cost.



Contact Person

Frau / Mrs. Anuroopa Dixit

Programme Officer

Regional Office New Delhi

c/o DLTA Complex,

3rd Floor,

R. K. Khanna Stadium,

1 Africa Avenue,

New Delhi 110029

Tel:  +91 11 66465505

Fax: +91 11 66465555

Email: dixit@daad.de

www.daad.in <http://www.daaddelhi.org/>

Kavitha

*****************************************************

*Henry Harvin® *is a *Global Edtech* company based out of US & India with a
customer base in 97+ Countries. We rank amongst the *Top 500 Edtech
companies globally* and *Top 100 Edtech* companies in India. We are working
with multiple Institutions like IIT Bombay, IIT Delhi, IIT Kharagpur, IIM
Ahmedabad, IIM Bangalore, IIM Calcutta, FORE School, XIMB, IIFT Kolkata,
and 110+ Prestige Institutes( Click Here
<https://www.henryharvin.com/college-training-reviews> to see the list).

Some of our notable *Corporate Clientele include* Sun Pharma,EY, Abbott,
Hostbooks, NTPC, SAB Miller, A-Paul Instruments, Eaton Corporation, Apollo
Tyres, Stanley Consultants, CG Power & Industries, Mega Cabs, Fidelity
Investments, MJ Logistics, UK India Business Council, Bajaj Finance, Hero
Group, Wunderman and many more

This Summer, We want to introduce our Flagship Career Development Programs
to the students of* IIT Palakkad *and make them industry-ready. We are
looking forward to* collaborating with your Club / Committee* and executing
the venture for the students of your college.

*Find below the most popular Course choices and the relevant details for
the same: *

   Implementation

   9. 1 Yr Gold Membership: Access to Henry Harvin Academy

> I am happy to inform you that our students have showcased an excellent
> performance in the first ever pan-IIT Yoga competition that concluded in
> IIT Bhilai today. The institute has won TWO first prizes, ONE second prize
> and THREE third prizes.
>
> Traditional yogasana single (male)
> 1st position: SUMAN MAJUMDER
>
> Rhythmic yogasana pair (male)
> 1st position: RAMAN PAREEK and DIPANSHU DUTTA
>
> Rhythmic yogasana (female)
> 2nd position: STEFFY BENNY and RITTIKA GHOSH
>
> Artistic yogasana(male)
> 3rd position: SUMAN MAJUMDER
>
> Artistic yogasana single(female)
> 3rd position: STEFFY BENNY
>
> Artistic yogasana pair(male)
> 3rd position: UTSAV PATEL and VAIBHAV NAGAR
>
>

> 2022, our institute qualified for the final round in all the eight
> participating events.

> represented our institute for this competition.
>

> Instructor Alok who wholeheartedly trained our students. Thanks to the
> Students' section and Dr. Projwal Banerjee for the logistic arrangements.

> students.

*****************************************************

Dear All,

I am happy to inform you that our students have showcased an excellent
performance in the first ever pan-IIT Yoga competition that concluded in
IIT Bhilai today. The institute has won TWO first prizes, ONE second prize
and THREE third prizes.

Traditional yogasana single (male)
1st position: SUMAN MAJUMDER

Rhythmic yogasana pair (male)
1st position: RAMAN PAREEK and DIPANSHU DUTTA

Rhythmic yogasana (female)
2nd position: STEFFY BENNY and RITTIKA GHOSH

Artistic yogasana(male)
3rd position: SUMAN MAJUMDER

Artistic yogasana single(female)
3rd position: STEFFY BENNY

Artistic yogasana pair(male)
3rd position: UTSAV PATEL and VAIBHAV NAGAR


In the initial selection process for the final round that was held in May
2022, our institute qualified for the final round in all the eight
participating events.

Please join me to congratulate all the medal winners and those who
represented our institute for this competition.

Special mention to our Yoga Instructor Priyam and Physical Training
Instructor Alok who wholeheartedly trained our students. Thanks to the
Students' section and Dr. Projwal Banerjee for the logistic arrangements.

Hope that this success will spur interest in yoga among the institute
students.

Thank you,
Jagadeesh
--
Prof. Dr. Jagadeesh Bayry,
Dean (Student Affairs),
Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad
Sikharam block, Nila Campus.

Dear all,
Greetings from the cultural council!

Hope you are safe and doing well. The council is glad to announce that we
are starting a repository for the cultural council where activities related
to all the clubs and other cultural events will be stored and made
available to the student community. It will be constantly updated once any
event/activity/workshop is done. Feel free to access it for viewing the
entries and relevant photos and videos related to the cultural activities.

Kindly note that the repository link will be available in each club's
Whatsapp group's description and in the sac portal under the cultural
section soon apart from this mail for convenient access.

Please find the link of the *Cultural Repository*
<https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1MovXsW0x2hTmpUwI0XTOq_DJIA8O22Zb?usp=sharing>
herewith.

--
Regards,
Sai Prakesh Vorluvothu
Secretary, Cultural Affairs
Indian Institute of Technology, Palakkad
Contact No:6301936477 | LinkedIn
<https://www.linkedin.com/in/sai-prakesh-vorluvothu-41a6641aa/>
Email: sec_arts@smail.iitpkd.ac.in

*Sl. No*

*Title*

*Author*

1

Introduction to the Theory of Lie Groups

Roger Godement

2

Lie Algebras and Lie Groups

Jean-Pierre Serre

3

Foundations of Differentiable Manifolds and Lie Groups

Frank W. Warner

4

Lie Groups

J.J. Duistermaat

5

Lie Groups, Lie Algebras, and Some of Their Applications

Robert Gilmore

6

Voices from the Lost Horizon: Stories and Songs of the Great Andamanese

Anvita Abbi


*Warm Regards, *

damage it” *

*― John Muir*

Dear All,
     Despite many reminders, many of you haven't filled out the form yet.
This is really important for us to plan the food, travel etc... for the
event as well as hostel accommodations. Do fill the form
https://forms.gle/CUJk7BazQjhA8pFU7 *before tomorrow 12 pm.* Every student
is supposed to fill the form without fail.

If you are already on campus and don't plan to go back home before 12th
August, fill the date of return as 11th or 12th August.

*****************************************************

Dear All,

                Since one of the cables connected between the substation
and feeder pillar provided near the playground has become out of order,
there will be a *shutdown of power supply* to this feeder pillar from *1.00pm
to 3.00pm tomorrow (08.07.22) *as part of inspection and rectification
activities. This feeder pillar is feeding supply to ground lights, four
temporary labs near ground, EWD office and CPWD office. The UPS provided in
the temporary labs are having 30 mins backup only. It is therefore
requested that the faculty and research scholars of Sangraha block
judiciously use the UPS during the period.

Regards,

Ganesh

Hello Everyone!
Greetings from the Finance club,

I'm very delighted to let you all know that the Finance club is now one
year old. The club was formed by J G Anurag <111801020@smail.iitpkd.ac.in>
 and Abhishek D Joy <111801036@smail.iitpkd.ac.in> under the mentorship of Dr.
Amrita Roy <amritaroy@iitpkd.ac.in> with an aim to inculcate a culture of
finance and foster financial literacy among the student community. Within a
span of one year, interactive keynote sessions, workshops, and competitions
were conducted. I thank the previous club heads and our faculty mentor for
their sincere efforts and setting such a high standard from the very
beginning.
I and Rajesh Budania <112102004@smail.iitpkd.ac.in> are honored to be the
new club heads. It's our commitment to take the club to new heights. We
endeavour to make this club a place to learn and more importantly, a place
to grow!
Be excited and get ready cause daily top financial news, curated content,
insightful sessions, workshops and intense competitions are all coming
along your way.

Below is the link to join our WhatsApp group:
https://chat.whatsapp.com/Et6CZ84mz9C1IXVMa0E8Wb

And make sure to follow our official Instagram handle
<https://instagram.com/financeclub_iitpkd?igshid=egp45f1fovxq>.

*To the Moon !!*

Thanks and regards,
Sonu Shaw
Head, Finance Club.

*****************************************************

DAY 231
31/05/2022

*GOOD/BAD VERSUS ORDERLY/DISORDERLY*

 Practice nonjudgment by opening your mind to seeing things beyond
judgmental analysis with a sense of curiosity and nuance. A few examples of
mindful spectrums of analysis are:
  ♦ Mature/immature
♦ Knowledgeable/ignorant
  ♦ Orderly/disorderly What are some things that you think of as “bad”?
Would it be possible to consider the possibility that they are actually the
result of immaturity, ignorance, or disorder? Journal your reflections on
this.

FORWARD TOGETHER
-- 
*Team MITRA*
*IIT Palakkad*
*Nila Campus Room# B-224A (Tilang Hostel)*
*Ahalia Campus#Hostel 3 (Left side Room)*
https://www.facebook.com/TEAM.MITRA.IIT.PALAKKAD
<https://www.facebook.com/TEAM.MITRA.IIT.PALAKKAD/?__cft__[0]=AZWnTfStvGlEXxtjgA1HgnDm-8s9Tn2cQ7hvMVz-Mn8flr9ZwNvDoYd2s9muzRozhOvnhjaSZ3uKZMEKAZ7UtfIStmZiExYfiKweNttjb6Iy26uHgaqcxhb4bkU2yOET96yGUmYzUnvCpztdg_FAsD_X6UlK2G1yqL7NAN651Z7pglMtbf3XUN57-fngOjJeNIk&__tn__=kK-R>

*****************************************************

DAY 280
21/07/2022

*EXERCISE FOR SEEING THINGS DIFFERENTLY *

♦ Get into a comfortable position, close your eyes, and take a few deep
breaths to relax.
  ♦ Rub your hands together and then hold them over your eyes.
  ♦ Notice the warmth of your hands through your eyelids.
  ♦ Imagine that the energy from your hands is healing your eyes,
recalibrating your vision, and opening your perspective.
♦ Take a few deep breaths with your hands over your eyes. Repeat a few
times, allowing yourself to become more and more relaxed and more open to
“seeing” things differently.

--FORWARD TOGETHER
*Team MITRA*
*IIT Palakkad*
*Nila Campus Room# B-224A (Tilang Hostel)*
*Ahalia Campus#Hostel 3 (Left side Room)*
