and PG students are free to have lunch from 12 to 1 PM (on their campus)
depending on their class schedule and travel to other campuses for the lab
sessions.*

            mso-table-rspace: 0px;
        }

        h1 a,
        h2 a {
            transition: .3s;
        }

        h1 a:hover,
        h2 a:hover {
            color: #0073E6 !important;
        }

        .btns a,
        .apps a {
            transition: .3s;
        }

        .btns a:hover {
            background-color: #000 !important;
        }

        .apps a:hover {
            opacity: .8;
        }

        .text_box {
            margin: 0;
            font-size: 15px;
            color: #101010;
            line-height: 24px;
        }

        .text_box p {
            margin: 0 0 15px;
            font-size: 15px;
            color: #101010;
            line-height: 24px;
        }

        .text_box p strong {
            font-weight: 600;
        }

        .text_box p a {
            color: #0073E6;
            text-decoration: none;
        }

        .text_box ul {
            margin: 0 0 15px;
        }

        .text_box li {
            margin: 0 0 10px;
            font-size: 15px;
            color: #101010;
            line-height: 22px;
        }

        .text_box li a {
            color: #0073E6;
            text-decoration: none;
        }

        .text_box li strong {
            font-weight: 600;
        }

        @media (max-width: 600px) {
            .bdr_sect {
                border: 1px solid #e7e7e7;
            }
            .hedr {
                padding: 10px 10px 0 !important;
                border-radius: 8px 8px 0 0;
            }
            .logo_box {
                padding: 15px 10px !important;
            }

            h1 {
                font-size: 18px !important;
                line-height: 24px !important;
                padding: 15px 0 0 !important;
            }

            h2 {
                font-size: 15px !important;
                line-height: 23px !important;
            }

            .left_img,
            .right_img {
                display: none !important;
            }

            .successful_box {
                padding: 30px 15px !important;
            }

            .successful_box p {
                font-size: 15px !important;
                line-height: 21px !important;
                margin-bottom: 15px !important;
            }

            .successful_box li {
                font-size: 15px !important;
                line-height: 21px !important;
                margin-bottom: 8px !important;
            }

            .apps {
                padding: 15px 12px !important;
            }

            .apps span {
                font-size: 16px !important;
            }

            .full {
                width: 100%;
            }

            .footer {
                padding: 20px 15px !important;
                border-radius: 0 0 8px 8px;
            }

            .footer div a {
                padding: 0 3px !important;
            }

            .btns a {
                padding: 12px 30px !important;
                font-size: 14px !important;
            }
            .disclaimer {
                font-size: 14px !important;
                line-height: 19px !important;
            }
        }
    </style>

Based on further requests, the deadline is extended to Monday for the last
time. Please note that any project can have a most of 2 students. Advisors
may ensure the same when endorsing the proposals.

*****************************************************

Dear students,

Since a lot of you are yet to finalise the topics and methodology for your
OELP projects we are extending the deadline till the end of this week
(Friday). Please upload your proposals by then so that you can begin your
work at the earliest.

*****************************************************

Dear students,

While the course registrations for the upcoming semester are being carried
out, we would like to begin the project allocation for the OELP. As you
might be aware, we have two course codes ID2801 (Sem 3) and ID3801 (Sem 5)
this time. A few faculty have given a list
<https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/14EFX3olM2Mt3N-PJJqOFuc4YdyBmbUGJWc6o3-2_70E/edit?usp=sharing>
of
projects to choose from (pay attention to the target semester that the
advisors have mentioned). We would like you to go through the list and
identify a project that interests you, contact the advisor and discuss.
Once you have finalised the scope and methodology, you are required to
write the proposal in the attached format and fill out the following form
<https://forms.gle/mFWAmpXEoVK3Q4WZA> with relevant details. You may form
teams (of max 2 students) and submit a single proposal. Please note that
the proposal must be endorsed by the advisor(s) for it to be accepted.
Alternately, if you have an idea for a project apart from the ones in list
you may discuss with any faculty of the institute and obtain their
willingness to advise your work. The same procedure must be followed to
submit the proposal. The forms must be filled by the 16th of August.
Meanwhile please remember to register for the course on the records portal.


Arvind and Krishna
OELP Coordinators
-- 
Krishna Sesha Giri
IIT Palakkad


*****************************************************

*Phrasal Verbs and correct usage*

Use the following to fill-in the blanks in the right tense and form.

a) Wipe away: Remove or erase with a wiping motion
b) Wipe down: Clean the exterior surface of an object, typically by hand
using a damp dishcloth or other cleaning cloth
c) Wipe up: Completely remove spilled liquid or solids, typically by hand
using a cloth, mop or sponge
d) Wipe out: eliminate or detroy something completely
e) Wrap up: cover or enclose something in paper or soft material.
f) Wrap up: finish something


1) The hardworking single mother sat and ..........................
Christmas presents for her three children, late into the night on Christmas
eve.

2) "It's getting late – let's ..............." said Suhas to the Fine Arts
Club members, practicing for the Drama Competition.

3) You cannot simply ................... the history of any country.

4) '.................... any and all kinds of grease with our all-purpose
cleaner', the advertisement stated.

5) After washing my car last evening, I .......it............... with an
old piece of cloth.

6) Will you ................... that ink spill please?

7) Genocide is the term used to describe how countries systematically
eliminate or ................... ethnic and religious minorities.

8) He ...................... the counters with a wet cloth, as part of
cleaning the kitchen.

9) I ..............the milk.............. off the floor, but I should have
just invited the dog in to lick it up.

10) Many poor people have their savings ................. by unforeseen
healthcare costs in the absence of a well-functioning public healthcare
system.

11) ......................... books in brown paper was a standard ritual
all through school life in India.

12) The film shooting progressed on schedule and the team was able to
................ and leave as planned.



Answers:

1) wrapped up (e)
2) wrap up (f)
3) wipe away (a)
4) Wipe away (a)
5) wiped it down (b)
6) wipe up (c)
7) wipe out (d)
8) wiped down (b)
9) wiped the milk up (c)
10) wiped out (d)
11) Wrapping up (e)
12) wrap up (f)

regards, Sandhya
-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

*Phrasal verbs and correct usage*

Use the correct forms of these phrasal verbs to fill-in the blanks and make
meaningful sentences

Think back: Think about a time or experience; to recall
Think over: Ponder or reflect on a subject
Think up: Create in one’s mind; to invent
Tip off: Alert or inform someone, especially confidentially
Try out: To try something new or different, to see if it is suitable or
pleasing

1) An anonymous caller .......................the police that the suspect
would be in the area.

2) ................the new menu at the hotel down the road, it's pretty
good.

3) ..............................to my childhood, I remember summers on the
beach in Nigeria.

4) She is raring to ................her new roller skates.

5) They ................... a new way of raising money for a Writing Centre
at the University.

6) Raghu need's some time to ............................. the job offer as
it will entail moving to Nagpur.

7) We have to ........................... an excuse, for not showing up on
time.

8) The police said that they had received a .................... about the
presence of explosives at the Market.

9) Let's ................... to the dawn of time.

10) I'll ............it................. and give you an answer next week.


1) tipped off
2) Try out
3) Thinking back
4) try out
5) thought up
6) think over
7) think up
8) tip-off
9) think back
10) think it over

regards, Sandhya
-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

“We are like the little branch that quivers during a storm, doubting our
strength and forgetting we are a tree - deeply rooted to withstand all of
life's upheavals.” *~ Dodinsky*

“Where do you see yourself in 5 years?” “Have you any idea what you’re
going to do with your life?” “You’re <insert your age>, it’s high time you
start planning your future.” - Ugh, there’s so much pressure to have it all
figured out and it only gets worse as we grow up.

The annoying part is that it just stops there. No one seems to have the
answer to “How exactly do I do that?” But maybe there’s something that you
can do to start the process? Yes, it’s a narrative exercise called the
“Tree of Life”.

Would you like to give it a shot? Here are the steps:
*Draw a Tree of Life*
The first step is to let loose your hidden inner artist. Don’t worry, it’s
not a competition and no one’s judging. So set yourself free!

Do you have an A3 sized sheet of paper and some colours lying around? Go
fetch them. Can’t find any? No worries, just stick a few sheets together
and use a pen/pencil instead.

Now draw a tree with the following parts:

*Roots: *Identify YOUR roots and label them with answers to -

   - Where do you come from? (Place you were born, education, people,
   ideas, traditions, belief, language etc)
   - How important are your roots to you and has their perception changed
   over time?
   - Does your past influence you?

*Ground: *Label the ground by identifying your current reality -

   - Where do you live and what are the activities you are engaged in daily
   life?
   - Is your ground flat or bumpy? (Stable or uncertain)
   - Do you have a favourite place that you visit?

*Trunk: *Label the trunk by identifying your skills and values -

   - What talents and coping skills do you have?
   - What do you believe you are good at?

*Branches: *Label the branches by identifying your hopes and goals -

   - What’d you aspire to become?
   - Do you wish for health, family, financial stability, happiness or all?
   - How achievable are your goals?

*Leaves: *Label the leaves by identifying people who’re significant in your
life -

   - People who play an important role in your life
   - Are they still with you or leaves in the wind?
   - What influence do they have on you?

*Flowers: *Label the flowers by identifying things that make you happy -

   - What makes you smile?
   - How often do you do those things?

*Fruits: *Label the fruits by identifying all your achievements so far -

   - Any prizes or rewards that you’ve won till now
   - How did those recognitions make you feel?

*Bugs: *Label the bugs by identifying challenges you are facing now -

   - Any issues across relationships, career or self?
   - What were some issues you experienced in the past?
   - How did you manage them?

Now let’s have a look at this beautiful tree of your life. What do you
think? Does it maybe give you a sense of who you are and what you want to
achieve? Whenever you find yourself doubting your future, maybe have a look
at this tree, or maybe even draw one again from scratch.
Looking for further guidance on understanding yourself? Why not get in
touch with an unbiased friend?

CONNECT TO AN EXPERT NOW
<https://yourdost.com/chatSession/?workgroup=demo@workgroup.chat.yourdost.com&yd_source=IITPKD_NL&yd_medium=IITPKDMailer&yd_campaign=TreeofLife>

In case of any queries/concerns, please feel free to write to us
campus@yourdost.com.


*Standing with you,Team YourDOST*

of lateral organization and factors that determine shapes of
multi-component fluid membranes as well as to the organisation cytoskeletal

fluctuations and hydrodynamic interactions." [1]*

*****************************************************

*Read the short passage and test your comprehension with the questions that
follow*

*Amazon Snakes!*

The Amazon rainforest is home to a wide variety of notorious, yet
fascinating, snakes. Some of the most deadly (and well-known) snakes in the
world—the green anaconda, the boa constrictor, the lancehead—live in the
Amazon.

Agile on water but awkward on land, the green anaconda is one of the
largest snakes in the world. At 29 feet long and about 250kg, these snakes
are huge! Most people assume that anacondas are very poisonous, but they
are actually non-venomous. Instead, they are constrictors, meaning they
squeeze their prey to death before swallowing it whole. The green anaconda
loves to lie in wait in shallow, slow moving waters like marshes, swamps,
and creeks.

The tree dwelling cousin to the green anaconda is the boa constrictor. Like
the green anaconda, the boa constrictor can also grow to be larger than
most snakes. These snakes prefer to wrap their six-foot-long bodies around
tree limbs, rather than slither through swamps. Because boas are so
muscular, they have no problem hanging on trees until it is time for a
snack. The boa has the capability to squeeze its prey to death and swallow
an entire animal in one bite. Eating such large meals allows this snake to
go weeks before eating again.

By contrast, the lancehead is a much smaller snake. It typically grows to
be about a foot long. Like the boa, the lancehead loves to curl itself
around tree limbs, but it is not strong enough or large enough to be a
constrictor. Despite its size, the lancehead is one of the most deadly
snakes in South America because it is extremely sneaky and venomous. It
stealthily hunts for its prey by using heat sensors in pits on the side of
its face. Once it detects a warm body, it strikes, releasing paralyzing
venom into its victim.

Long and strong green anacondas, constricting boas, and life-threatening
lanceheads are just a few of the deadly variety of snakes that dwell in the
Amazon rainforest.


1) As used in paragraph 1, which of the following choices gives the best
DEFINITION for the word
notorious?
A. included in popular culture
B. famous or commonly celebrated
C. widely and unfavorably known
D. evil or malintentioned

2) According to information in the passage, both green anacondas and boa
constrictors

I. squeeze their prey before eating it whole
II. are larger than most other snakes
III. love curling themselves around trees
A. I only
B. I and II only
C. II and III only
D. I, II, and III


3) Based on its use in paragraph 2, it can be understood that agile belongs
to which of the following word groups?

A. gentle, soft, light
B. athletic, nimble, quick
C. secret, stealthy, hidden
D. gigantic, huge, enormous


4) According to information in the passage, the boa constrictor is

A. extremely venomous
B. the deadliest snake in South America
C. always looking for its next meal
D. six feet long

5) Which of the following statements from the passage best summarizes how
boa constrictors differ from green anacondas?

A. “Like the boa, the Lancehead loves to curl itself around tree limbs, but
it is not strong enough or large enough to be a constrictor.”
B. “Agile on water but awkward on land, the Green Anaconda is one of the
largest snakes in the world."
C. “The boa has the capability to squeeze its prey to death and swallow an
entire animal in one bite.”
D. “These snakes prefer to wrap their six-foot-long bodies around tree
limbs, rather than slither through swamps.”

6) Which of the following choices correctly orders these snakes from
smallest to largest in terms of length?

A. Lancehead, Boa Constrictor, Green Anaconda
B. Green Anaconda, Boa Constrictor, Lancehead
C. Lancehead, Green Anaconda, Boa Constrictor
D. Boa Constrictor, Lancehead, Green Anaconda,

7) According to the passage, how is the lancehead different from both the
boa constrictor and the green anaconda?

I. It injects paralyzing venom into its prey.
II. It curls itself around tree limbs.
III. It searches out its prey, rather than lying in wait.

A. I only
B. I and II only
C. I and III only
D. I, II, and III


*Answer Key*
1-C, 2-B, 3-B, 4-D, 5-D, 6-A, 7-C

regards, Sandhya

-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss

*****************************************************

Hello Everyone!

Greetings from Yet Another Coding Club (YACC) IITPKD!! Hope you all are
doing well.

Yet Another Coding Club (YACC) is conducting a series of competitive
programming contests. These contests will be beginner-friendly contests
with little to no prerequisites required. So, it's a very good opportunity
for all who know some programming language and want to start up with
Competitive programming.

The 9th Training Programming contest will be conducted *tomorrow* *(Saturday,
15th October), from 9:05 PM - 11:05 PM*. The platform will be Codeforces.
Kindly create an account in advance. We have also booked the *ground floor
Computer Lab* in the Ahalia campus in case anyone wants to give the contest
in the lab, although it is not compulsory to do so.

You need to register for the contest before it starts. The registration
phase will start 6 hours before the Contest. The doubt discussion session
will be held on *Sunday(16th October) from 2:00 PM - 5:00 PM*.

We highly encourage everyone to read all the problems and participate in
the discussion session on Sunday to solve the unsolved problems.


*From this contest onwards, YACC will also maintain a common leaderboard
for all training contests, and prizes will be given to the overall and
batch-wise leaders after a few contests!*
Contest link: Contest Link
<https://codeforces.com/contestInvitation/d582207bc3e2335a5efb02c1f01dbf353b174e8f>

For those who do not know what CP is, have a look at this YouTube
video : Introduction
to CP <https://youtu.be/xAeiXy8-9Y8>
For an introduction to the Codeforces platform : Introduction to Codeforces
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fbNRCXRJ76E>
For more clarification on how to submit on the Codeforces platform :
Document
<https://docs.google.com/document/d/1t-aKEUXTgXAf-di0o5eOveNm9ziAgExTT-XzMv_uI64/edit>


*Join YACC on Discord*: https://discord.gg/sVtEgQCqCk

Thanks and Regards,
*Yet Another Coding Club (YACC)*
*IIT Palakkad*

*****************************************************

*Reading Comprehension*

Read the following passage and attempt the questions that follow to test
your understanding:

Excerpt from the WHO report " Guidelines on mental health promotive and
preventive interventions for adolescents (2020)"

As adolescents transition from childhood to adulthood, they undergo a
number of significant physical,
social and psychological changes. These include rapid neurological
development and associated
vulnerability to a range of positive and negative influences. Issues such
as poverty, conflict,
community violence, forced migration, gender inequality and humanitarian
emergencies can increase
the likelihood of a range of adverse experiences. Factors such as early and
forced marriage, gender based
violence, adolescent pregnancy, poor nutrition, noncommunicable and
infectious diseases and
dropping out of school can predispose individuals to mental health
conditions. The more risk factors
adolescents are exposed to, the greater the potential impact on their
mental health.

Young people face increasingly complex social, cultural and economic
environments with growing
challenges, including increases in forced displacement, migration, unstable
families, income
inequalities, rising levels of mental health problems and violence. Mental
health conditions account
for a considerable proportion of the global disease burden during
adolescence and are the leading
cause of disability in young people. Up to 50% of all mental health
conditions start before the age of
14 years. Suicide is one of the three leading causes of death among
adolescents. Poor adolescent
mental health portends a range of risky behaviours, including self-harm,
tobacco, alcohol and other
substance use, risky sexual behaviours and violence, the effects of which
persist throughout the lifecourse.

Inequities, including those linked to poverty and gender, shape all aspects
of adolescent health
and well-being. Young disadvantaged people from minority and migrant
communities are affected
disproportionately, with poorer mental health outcomes and higher rates of
unemployment and early
school leaving. Females, particularly young girls, face double the risk of
common mental disorders
compared to males. Along with this, depression is also reported to be more
persistent in women
than men. This higher prevalence of common mental health illnesses also
reflects the unmet need
for mental health treatment in women. Sociocultural factors, such as lower
education, poverty,
exposure to domestic violence and abuse and low decision-making power tend
to increase the risk of
depression in girls and women.

1) " adolescents transition from childhood to adulthood", so the correct
temporal sequence is
a) adolescent, child, adult
b) child, adolescent, adult
c) adult, adolescent, child

2) to be "affected disproportionately" means
a) to be affected more than others
b) to be affected severely
c) to be affected more than expected

3) Which of the following statements does the passage support?
a) About half the people under 14 have a mental health condition
b) One is three teenagers may commit suicide
c) Adolescent girls face more risk factors that may cause mental illness

4) Mental health is not always addressed by just counselling the
individual, but also requires addressing social conditions of living. Which
sentence supports this statement?
a) Inequities, including those linked to poverty and gender, shape all
aspects of adolescent health and well-being.
b) Young disadvantaged people from minority and migrant communities are
affected disproportionately, with poorer mental health outcomes.
c) Sociocultural factors, such as lower education, poverty, exposure to
domestic violence and abuse and low decision-making power tend to increase
the risk of depression in girls and women.
d) all of the above

5)  "Females, particularly young girls, face double the risk of common
mental disorders
compared to males. Along with this, depression is also reported to be more
persistent in women
than men." This means
a) depression is not a common mental disorder
b) women tend to suffer depression for a longer time than men
c) both (a) and (b)


Answers
1) b
2) a
3) c
4) d
5) b

regards, Sandhya
  --
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

Dear Sandhya,
   I thank you for choosing this passage as an exercise. The month of
October is very special with respect to promotion of mental health as Oct
10th is observed as World Mental Health Day. Whether it was deliberate or
not I am so happy that you did your part in creating awareness of mental
health in our community through this exercise. Looking forward to such
active participation from you in the future as well.

Regards
Tessy

> *Reading Comprehension*
>
> Read the following passage and attempt the questions that follow to test
> your understanding:
>
> Excerpt from the WHO report " Guidelines on mental health promotive and
> preventive interventions for adolescents (2020)"
>
> As adolescents transition from childhood to adulthood, they undergo a
> number of significant physical,
> social and psychological changes. These include rapid neurological
> development and associated
> vulnerability to a range of positive and negative influences. Issues such
> as poverty, conflict,
> community violence, forced migration, gender inequality and humanitarian
> emergencies can increase
> the likelihood of a range of adverse experiences. Factors such as early
> and forced marriage, gender based
> violence, adolescent pregnancy, poor nutrition, noncommunicable and
> infectious diseases and
> dropping out of school can predispose individuals to mental health
> conditions. The more risk factors
> adolescents are exposed to, the greater the potential impact on their
> mental health.
>
> Young people face increasingly complex social, cultural and economic
> environments with growing
> challenges, including increases in forced displacement, migration,
> unstable families, income
> inequalities, rising levels of mental health problems and violence. Mental
> health conditions account
> for a considerable proportion of the global disease burden during
> adolescence and are the leading
> cause of disability in young people. Up to 50% of all mental health
> conditions start before the age of
> 14 years. Suicide is one of the three leading causes of death among
> adolescents. Poor adolescent
> mental health portends a range of risky behaviours, including self-harm,
> tobacco, alcohol and other
> substance use, risky sexual behaviours and violence, the effects of which
> persist throughout the lifecourse.
>
> Inequities, including those linked to poverty and gender, shape all
> aspects of adolescent health
> and well-being. Young disadvantaged people from minority and migrant
> communities are affected
> disproportionately, with poorer mental health outcomes and higher rates of
> unemployment and early
> school leaving. Females, particularly young girls, face double the risk of
> common mental disorders
> compared to males. Along with this, depression is also reported to be more
> persistent in women
> than men. This higher prevalence of common mental health illnesses also
> reflects the unmet need
> for mental health treatment in women. Sociocultural factors, such as lower
> education, poverty,
> exposure to domestic violence and abuse and low decision-making power tend
> to increase the risk of
> depression in girls and women.
>
> 1) " adolescents transition from childhood to adulthood", so the correct
> temporal sequence is
> a) adolescent, child, adult
> b) child, adolescent, adult
> c) adult, adolescent, child
>
> 2) to be "affected disproportionately" means
> a) to be affected more than others
> b) to be affected severely
> c) to be affected more than expected
>
> 3) Which of the following statements does the passage support?
> a) About half the people under 14 have a mental health condition
> b) One is three teenagers may commit suicide
> c) Adolescent girls face more risk factors that may cause mental illness
>
> 4) Mental health is not always addressed by just counselling the
> individual, but also requires addressing social conditions of living. Which
> sentence supports this statement?
> a) Inequities, including those linked to poverty and gender, shape all
> aspects of adolescent health and well-being.
> b) Young disadvantaged people from minority and migrant communities are
> affected disproportionately, with poorer mental health outcomes.
> c) Sociocultural factors, such as lower education, poverty, exposure to
> domestic violence and abuse and low decision-making power tend to increase
> the risk of depression in girls and women.
> d) all of the above
>
> 5)  "Females, particularly young girls, face double the risk of common
> mental disorders
> compared to males. Along with this, depression is also reported to be more
> persistent in women
> than men." This means
> a) depression is not a common mental disorder
> b) women tend to suffer depression for a longer time than men
> c) both (a) and (b)
>
>
> Answers
> 1) b
> 2) a
> 3) c
> 4) d
> 5) b
>
> regards, Sandhya
>   --
> English Language Support & Services
> IIT Palakkad
> https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss
>
>

-- 
Dr.Tessy Grace Mathews
Counsellor,IIT-PKD
Contact No: 9778348865

Dear students,

You might aware of recent incidence on the missing laptops from Hostel 4 of
Ahalia.

It is important to keep the doors locked while you are not in the room.

In addition, you don't have any rights to enter other rooms and pickup the
things. Not only you are creating unnecessary scenes, tension in the
community but also innocent students get blame.

We will identify the student who created the scene of last week and take
action. The time of Institute and public staff are precious and don't
misuse them for your fun.

In the future, the punishment for such cases will be of harsh one.

Thank you,
Jagadeesh

Prof. Dr. Jagadeesh Bayry,

*****************************************************

Hey everyone!

Hope you’re keeping well.

As the new academic year dawns upon us, so does our responsibility to guide
the latest batch of freshers. First order of business, we have to provide
them with the admission brochure , which will contain all the preliminary
details of getting inducted into our institute. This will also serve as a
first look into our college for any outsider, hence making it a very
important booklet. It’ll be prominently displayed in all our media pages,
as well as the JoSAA website. If you feel like you can contribute to the
building of this brochure by being a part of either the *design team* or
the *content creation team*, do fill the form below *before tomorrow
(6/8/22) night*. You might want to know that there might be some rewards
waiting down this road for you.

https://forms.gle/HMUh4bo1GzWMJKeP7

For any more queries, you can contact me or the other secretaries.

Jyothiradithya

Students' General Secretary

Student Affairs Council | Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad
+91- <+91-6351088949>9846188577
gen_sec@smail.iitpkd.ac.in
sac.iitpkd.ac.in <https://sac.iitpkd.ac.in:8090>

*****************************************************

*English Idioms*

Clearly, the English think a lot about money, as there are even more
idioms related to it:

1. Midas touch

To be able to make money easily. This idiom comes from the story of King
Midas, who turned everything he touched into gold.

“ Shweta really has the Midas touch. Every business she starts becomes very
successful.”

2. In the red/In the black

To lose more money than you make.

“I’m in the red this month after too many trips to the FoodCourt. I plan to
offer Maths tuition to the private school students for extra money.”

The opposite of being in the red is being in the black, which means that
you’ve made more money than you spent.

“After working a couple of small jobs over the weekend, I earned an extra
Rs1500 and am back in the black.”

3. Receive a kickback

To receive money illegally/to receive bribes.

“The police chief was arrested after the news reported he was receiving
kickbacks from criminals to ignore certain crimes.”

“The traffic cop receives kickbacks for not writing tickets to politicians'
drivers.”

4. Living hand to mouth

To live without a lot of money/ with just enough money for basic needs.

“The family has been living hand to mouth ever since their father lost his
job during the lockdown.”

5. To be loaded

To have a lot of money.

“Baiju paid his Harvard Law School tuition with cash. His family is loaded.”

regards, Sandhya
-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

DAY 276
17/07/2022

*LETTING GO OF ATTACHMENT TO OUTCOMES*

  ♦ Get comfortable, set a timer for at least five minutes, and begin to
meditate. ♦ As you breathe, exhale into deep relaxation.
  ♦ Settle into a sense of relaxed stillness.
♦ Observe the specific thoughts, images, and ideas passing through your
mind.
  ♦ Identify a specific thought or idea as it arises, and tell yourself, “I
have attachments about ___, but I am willing to let them go and see things
differently.”
  ♦ Bring your awareness back to the breath and identify the next thought
that comes up, repeating the statement until the timer goes off.


--FORWARD TOGETHER
*Team MITRA*
*IIT Palakkad*

Dear Candidate,







Greetings from ETS India Resource Center managed by DP Cube Learning.



Here are a few important reasons why you should choose GRE® General Test:

Take the test that is accepted by thousands of graduate schools worldwide, including INDIA: You can take the test now, even if you are still deciding what to do. 90+ institutes accept the GRE Scores in India including IIMs.



Use the test-taker friendly design to do your best: You can preview questions, skip and go back to more challenging questions and even change your answers, all within a section.



Send only your best scores: GRE® tests provide the ScoreSelect® option, which means you can take

GRE test once now, or again in the future, and only send the GRE test scores from whichever test date(s) you want schools to see. Best of all, you always have five years to decide how to use any of your scores.



GRE Exam fee:

The GRE examination fee in India is USD 213.

 



                                         [A black background with white text  Description automatically generated with low confidence] <https://www.ets.org/mygre>

Dear Students,

This is a call for *one EL-Buddy volunteer *from among the *students on
Ahalia campus* for the* month of July*.

If you think your English is good and can devote an hour a day on weekdays
to speak with, and assist a fellow student improve their English language
skills, please meet me, by prior appointment, during working hours in Room
122, for a discussion and briefing.

This is an unpaid position, but you will get a Volunteer Certificate for
satisfactory performance in the role.

thanks and regards, Sandhya

Hello there!!
To all the dance enthusiasts out there.
Gear up! We shall dance this semester break away with OFF-BEAT, a dance
move challenge, presented to you by Sync to Beat, the dance club of IIT
Palakkad.

Given below are a few examples of the dance moves/skills that we urge you
to try out. You may also come up with other dance moves that you are
interested in.
All your entries will be featured on the official Instagram handle of Sync
to Beat.
Keep in mind that your participation will fetch you a position on the
leaderboard.

Upload your video entries through this g-form:
https://forms.gle/AByDhF7SmziWpEhy6

Regards and Best Wishes,

*****************************************************

Dear All,

Dr. Gayathri V, who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Florida,
will be giving a talk on *May 13 in room 18 at Ahaiya academic block from
3:15-4:15 pm.*

She is working in the exciting field of Gravitational-wave astronomy and is
part of the LIGO collaboration. She will be giving a talk which will be at
the colloquium level and would thus be relevant for most of us here at IIT
Palakkad. I invite you all to attend her talk. The details of her talk are
given below.

Title: Who ordered LIGO's most massive black hole?
Abstract:
We know of the existence of so-called stellar-mass black holes that form
when stars die, and much heavier, supermassive black holes located in the
centers of galaxies. It has been an open question whether there is anything
between these two populations, in the mass range of 10^2-10^5 solar masses.
These so-called intermediate mass black holes could be a missing link that
connects the supermassive and stellar-mass black hole populations. The LIGO
and Virgo gravitational wave observatories are sensitive to collisions of
black holes with up to about 10^3 solar masses. They have already started
seeing black holes that are more massive than what we expected from stars.
I will outline possible ways intermediate mass black holes can form in the
universe and discuss what we learned about the possible origin of such
events from LIGO-Virgo's observations so far.

Best,
Projjwal

DAY 244
13/06/2022

*BLESSINGS ON BLESSINGS *

Imagine that every single word you speak sends thousands of invisible foot
soldiers out into the world to do your bidding. Imagine that those foot
soldiers do exactly what you say, only that they first do it to you and
then to the world around you. Practice speaking life, liberation, and
happiness into the world through encouraging, loving words of affirmation
to everyone you come in contact with today

FORWARD TOGETHER

Dear Professors/ Researchers/ Scientists/Students,

*   Greetings from Providence College of Engineering, Chengannur, Kerala,
India*

We are pleased to inform you that the Department of Science and Humanities,
Providence College of Engineering, Chengannur, Kerala, India is organizing
a three day NATIONAL CONFERENCE ON NANOMATERIALS (NANOPHILIA 2022) from
August 25th to 27th 2022.

The Faculty members, Research Scholars, and Students are invited to submit
abstracts and full length manuscripts of their original research works
related to the conference theme as provided in the brochure. The authors
will get a chance to publish their manuscript in conference proceedings
with ISBN number. Please refer to the brochure to get the information about
last dates of each submission.

Herewith I am enclosing the conference brochure for your kind reference. To
register kindly scan the QR code or use the following link
prvdnc.com/nanophilia

Dear Students,

The IIT Bay Area Alumni (IITBAA) is non-profit organisation run by IIT
Alumni settled in San Francisco Bay Area which is dedicated to the
professional advancement of alumni from all IIT campuses throughout India.
As part of their efforts, they are launching a portal to connect employers
and job-seekers (among IIT students and alumni). It's a new but promising
initiative. Current and former students who are interested in grabbing this
opportunity can register in the portal (whose link is in the trailing
mail).

Regards
Deepak

*****************************************************

*Consider the following phrasal verbs and use them appropriately in the
sentences that follow*

a. Sleep in: Sleep late; to go on sleeping past one’s customary or planned
hour
b. Sleep on: Postpone (a decision) at least overnight, but sometimes longer
c. Sort out: Clarify by reviewing mentally
d. Sort out: Fix, as a problem
e. Sort out: Organise or separate into groups, as a collection of items, so
as to make tidy
f. Sort out: Separate from the remainder of a group


1. There were some things he needed to ................. before he got into
another serious relationship

2. She is trying to ......................childcare, before she joins the
new job.

3. Meeta decide she had been slogging too hard the entire week, so decided
to ............................. on Sunday.

4. Ravi was unable to decide between taking up a postdoc offer from the US
or Germany, so he decided to.................... the matter for as long as
he could

5. We must ...................the good apples from the bad ones.

6. It took ages to ................ the documentation needed to get into
the country - what a task!

7. .........................any clothes you no longer use and give them to
me, to give away.

8. There are one or two things to.......................... before I leave.

9. Could you ................. these paper clips by colour for me?

10. When in college, to ................... on everday of the week, during
the first week of vacation after gruelling semester exams, was what most
students liked to do.

11. Let me ....................... this, Preethi said, to her son's request
to join a residential camp in the midst of a pandemic

12. We need to call in an electrician to .............the wiring.

13. The police were called to .................... a domestic quarrel that
turned violent.

14. To grade cashew nuts, producers first ............ them.......... by
size.

*Answers*

1. There were some things he needed to ......c........... before he got
into another serious relationship

2. She is trying to .......d...............childcare, before she joins the
new job.

3. Meeta decide she had been slogging too hard the entire week, so decided
to ..........a................... on Sunday.

4. Ravi was unable to decide between taking up a postdoc offer from the US
or Germany, so he decided to.........b........... the matter for as long as
he could

5. We must .........f..........the good apples from the bad ones.

6. It took ages to .......d......... the documentation needed to get into
the country - what a task!

7. ..............f...........any clothes you no longer use and give them to
me, to give away.

8. There are one or two things to............c/d.............. before I
leave.

9. Could you .....e............ these paper clips by colour for me?

10. When in college, to .........a.......... on everday of the week, during
the first week of vacation after gruelling semester exams, was what most
students liked to do.

11. Let me ........b............... this, Preethi said, to her son's
request to join a residential camp in the midst of a pandemic

12. We need to call in an electrician to .....d........the wiring.

13. The police were called to ......d............. a domestic quarrel that
turned violent.

14. To grade cashew nuts, producers first ............ them.......... by
size.(e)

regards, Sandhya
-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss

DAY 294
23/08/2022

*TIME TRAVEL AND UNCONDITIONAL LOVE *

1. Set a timer for at least five minutes and sit comfortably.
2. Recall one of your earliest and most significant memories.
3. Visualize yourself time traveling back to that moment.
4. Imagine that you are able to communicate directly with your past self in
that moment.
5. Encourage, inspire, and forgive them with the wisdom you’ve gained since
then.
6. Offer your past self unconditional acceptance and love.

FORWARD TOGETHER
-- 
*Team MITRA*
*IIT Palakkad*
*Nila Campus Room# B-224A (Tilang Hostel)*

*****************************************************

DAY 334
15/10/2022

*COUNTING BY TWO MEDITATION *

Practice maintaining mental alertness by counting by two:
 1. Set a timer for five minutes or more.
 2. Breathe in and out comfortably, allowing the body to be relaxed.
 3. Begin counting by two: two . . . four . . . six . . . eight . . . 10 .
. .
 4. Observe the thoughts that arise in the mind and return to two when you
lose count or reach 100.
5. Keep the mind alert and awake until your timer goes off.


--

*Team MITRA*
*IIT Palakkad*

*****************************************************

Hello everyone,
I hope this email finds you well.

Shutterbug, the photography club of IIT Palakkad is welcoming new members!
Everyone who is interested in photography, be it those with prior
experience or those who want to learn any aspect of photography are
welcomed to fill out the form <https://forms.gle/V1tg548E7sjrKqWv9> and
become a part of the club.

Form link: https://forms.gle/V1tg548E7sjrKqWv9

The deadline for filling out the form is 4th July 2022 11:59 pm. Please
note this is the last call for recruitment before the next session.

For any further queries or concerns, feel free to contact me.

--
Thanks and Regards,

Garima Ranjan,
Shutterbug Head

> Link: https://zoom.us/j/6078606060?pwd=R2JzVCtESjBRdFZVOHVLR3BQWldlZz09
>
>
> Meeting ID: 607 860 6060
>
> Password: z6hY5V

>
> *A brief abstract of the talk: *The rapid increase in computational
> power, coupled with the improvements in numerical modeling and availability
> of performance data provides a unique opportunity to enhance the resilience
> and sustainability of spatially distributed infrastructure systems. This
> talk introduces the development of analytics-driven models to support the
> design and service-life management of infrastructure systems. Machine
> learning methods are used to perform rapid post-hazard-event assessments of
> the damage and functional state of impacted infrastructure systems and
> components. The analytics-driven framework is presented as a viable
> alternative to the traditional approach, which relies heavily on visual
> inspections and subjective estimates of the state of an infrastructure
> system. The machine learning methods presented in this talk are used to (1)
> develop bridge-specific fragility curves for more than 24,000 concrete
> box-girder California bridges, and (2) generate real-time estimates of the
> spatial distribution and severity of building damage following an
> earthquake.
>
>
> *Brief Bio of the speaker: *
>
>                                        Sujith Mangalathu is the Vice
> President of JP Morgan & Chase in Data Science wing. An alumnus of IIT
> Madras, he was a MEEES scholar at Rose School, Pavia, Italy. He graduated
> with a Ph.D. in structural engineering from the Georgia Institute of
> Technology in 2017. He spent two years as a post-doctoral research scholar
> at the University of California, Los Angeles. His research interest
> includes the application of machine learning techniques to support the
> design and service life management of structural and infrastructure
> systems. He has developed innovative methods for regional risk assessment
> using advanced statistical and machine learning techniques. He is a
> recipient of the prestigious Nevada Medal for Bridge Engineering in 2017.
> He is the bronze medalist winner of the first machine learning-based image
> challenge competition, PEER Hub ImageNet Challenge, organized by the
> University of California, Berkeley in 2018. He has published over 60 peer
> reviewed journal articles in various prestigious journals.
>
>
> with regards
>
> Gokulnath
>


*****************************************************

Dear All,

              Dr Sujith Mangalathu, Vice President, JP Morgan & Chase in
Data Science wing, USA, will be presenting a seminar on "*Analytics-Driven
Models to Support the Design and Service-Life Management of Infrastructure
Systems" *in *Room No: 305 at Nila campus (Samgatha building)* on  *18th
May 2022 (Wednesday) at 3:30 PM.*


All are invited to attend the talk.


The technical talk will also be broadcast by following the zoom link for
those who like to attend the same online.


Link: https://zoom.us/j/6078606060?pwd=R2JzVCtESjBRdFZVOHVLR3BQWldlZz09


Meeting ID: 607 860 6060

Password: z6hY5V


*A brief abstract of the talk: *The rapid increase in computational power,
coupled with the improvements in numerical modeling and availability of
performance data provides a unique opportunity to enhance the resilience
and sustainability of spatially distributed infrastructure systems. This
talk introduces the development of analytics-driven models to support the
design and service-life management of infrastructure systems. Machine
learning methods are used to perform rapid post-hazard-event assessments of
the damage and functional state of impacted infrastructure systems and
components. The analytics-driven framework is presented as a viable
alternative to the traditional approach, which relies heavily on visual
inspections and subjective estimates of the state of an infrastructure
system. The machine learning methods presented in this talk are used to (1)
develop bridge-specific fragility curves for more than 24,000 concrete
box-girder California bridges, and (2) generate real-time estimates of the
spatial distribution and severity of building damage following an
earthquake.


*Brief Bio of the speaker: *

                                       Sujith Mangalathu is the Vice
President of JP Morgan & Chase in Data Science wing. An alumnus of IIT
Madras, he was a MEEES scholar at Rose School, Pavia, Italy. He graduated
with a Ph.D. in structural engineering from the Georgia Institute of
Technology in 2017. He spent two years as a post-doctoral research scholar
at the University of California, Los Angeles. His research interest
includes the application of machine learning techniques to support the
design and service life management of structural and infrastructure
systems. He has developed innovative methods for regional risk assessment
using advanced statistical and machine learning techniques. He is a
recipient of the prestigious Nevada Medal for Bridge Engineering in 2017.
He is the bronze medalist winner of the first machine learning-based image
challenge competition, PEER Hub ImageNet Challenge, organized by the
University of California, Berkeley in 2018. He has published over 60 peer
reviewed journal articles in various prestigious journals.


with regards

Gokulnath


*****************************************************

*Use the following phrasal verbs, in the right tense, to make meaningful
sentences*

a) Show up: Appear, arrive, or attend, especially suddenly or erratically
b) Show up: Make visible or expose faults and deficiencies in, usually by
comparison
c) Shower with: Give to someone an abundance of (something)
d) Shut down: terminate or end, often permanently
e) Shut down: Turn off or stop
f) Shut (someone or something) in: Lock in
g) Shut out: block something from the mind.
h) Shut (someone or something) out: keep someone or something out of a
place or situation.

1) The computer had to be ................ and re-started.

2) I did not notice the dark pigments on my forehead in my dimly lit room,
but they did .......................... clearly in the magnifying washroom
mirror and bright lights of the star hotel.

3) The young faculty member was ................................... praise
for his penchant for research and publication.

4) After one particular bad exam result, Dileep ............ himself
........... the bedroom for an hour.

5) After the dog had chewed the third pair of slippers in a month, we were
forced to ............ it ............... of the house.

6) The old lady's son has been missing for many years, but the neighbours
think he might .............................. for the property now that she
is on her deathbed.

7) Ramu was .................................. so much love and affection
growing up, that it's hard to believe he told his therapist he felt unloved
and unwanted.

8) Listening to music is a good way to ............................
unwanted thoughts.

9) They ................ the noise by closing the thick mahogany door.

10) Big Bazaar had to ...................... for reasons still not clear to
anybody.

11) Hema was the first to ....................... for breakfast.

12) It's a good idea to have the spell-check on. That way, mistakes will
.......................... with a green squiggly line under them.

13) The crew ................. the right-hand engine of the aircraft
suspecting it was faulty.

14) Vivek.............. himself ........... his office, telling his
secretary to hold all calls, on a particularly crazy day.

15) Sandra refused to go back to school or stay in touch with classmates to
..................... all the memories of her bullying.

16)  The factory had to ..................... indefinitely after that
labour unions threatened the management.


*Answer Key*
1-(e), 2(b),3-(c) [showered with], 4-f, 5-h, 6-a, 7-c [showered with], 8-g,
9-g, 10-d, 11-a,12-b,13-e,14-f,15-g,16-d,


regards, Sandhya
-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss

us all come together to destigmatize mental health.

*****************************************************

*What Are Idioms?- A new series*

An idiom is a phrase whose meaning isn’t obvious from looking at the
individual words.

Idioms often rely on analogies and metaphors.

Because they’re used so often in everyday English, if you don’t know them,
it’s almost impossible to understand the context.

Learning common idioms in English will help you fit in with most real life
situations, involving English conversation

The words in idioms often seem totally random or strange when translated
literally.

The key to understanding English idioms is never to look at them or read
them in a literal sense—the words just won’t make sense together. Instead,
you need to learn them in context so you can understand their true meaning.

We’ll start with idioms in English that have some common verbs and then
common prepositions that you already recognize.

Then we’ll move on to common idioms and phrases for money, body parts, food
and nature.


*English Idioms with Common Verbs*
1. *Hit the books*


Literally, hit the books means to physically hit, punch or slap your
reading books. However, this is a commonly used expression among students,
especially American college students who have a lot of studying to do. It
simply means “*to study*,” and is a way of telling your friends that you’re
going to study.

It could be for a final exam, a midterm test or even an English exam.

“Sorry but I can’t watch the game with you tonight, I have to hit the
books. I have a huge exam next week!”

2.* Hit the sack*

Just like the first idiom, the literal meaning of this would be physically
hitting or beating a sack (a large bag usually used for carrying things in
bulk such as flour, rice or even soil). But actually to hit the sack means *to
go to bed*, and you’d use this to tell your friends or family that you’re
really tired, so you’re going to sleep.

Instead of saying hit the sack you can also say hit the hay.

“It’s time for me to hit the sack, I’m so tired.”

3. *Twist someone’s arm*


To twist someone’s arm literally means to take a person’s arm and turn it
around, which could be really painful if you take it exactly word-for-word.

If your arm has been twisted it means that *someone has done a great job of
convincing you to do something you might not have wanted to to do.*

And if you manage to twist someone else’s arm it means that you’re great at
convincing them, and they’ve finally agreed to do something after you’ve
been begging them.

“James, you should really come to the freshers welcome party tonight!”

“You know I can’t, I have to *hit the books* (study).”

“C’mon, you have to come! It’s going to be so much fun and there are going
to be lots of games and good food. Please come?”

“Good food ? Oh all right, *you’ve twisted my arm*, I’ll come!”

4.
*Stab someone in the back*

If we take this idiom literally, it would mean taking a knife or another
sharp object and putting it, with force, into a person’s back.

However, as an idiom, to stab someone in the back means *to hurt someone
who was close to us and trusted us by betraying them secretly and breaking
their trust*. We call the person who does this a back stabber.

“Did you hear that Shaily stabbed Mallica in the back last week?”

“No! I thought they were best friends, what did she do?”

“She told their boss that Mallica wasn’t interested in a promotion at work
and Shaily got it instead.”

“Wow, that’s the ultimate betrayal! No wonder they’re not friends anymore.”

5. *Lose your touch*

Literally, this means to no longer have the ability to touch or feel with
your fingers or hands.

But to lose your touch actually means that you *lose an ability or talent
you once had when dealing with things, people or situations*.

We use this when you’re usually good at a certain skill or talent, but then
things start to go wrong.

“I don’t understand why none of the vegetables I planted have sprouted.”

“It looks like you’ve lost your touch with gardening.”

“Oh no, I used to have green fingers, what happened?”


regards, Sandhya
-- 
English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss


*****************************************************

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: IAEA Marie Sklodowska-Curie Fellowship Programme <MSCFP@iaea.org>
Date: Fri, Jul 15, 2022 at 4:50 PM
Subject: IAEA Marie Sklodowska-Curie Fellowship Programme (MSCFP) New
Application Period Opens!
To:


Dear Recipient,



We are pleased to inform you that the 3rd IAEA Maria Sklodowska-Curie
Fellowship Programme (MSCFP) *application period is now open and will close
on September 30, 2022.*  To read more about the programme and eligibility
requirements please visit the link:  IAEA Marie Sklodowska-Curie Fellowship
Programme | IAEA
<https://www.iaea.org/about/overview/gender-at-the-iaea/iaea-marie-sklodowska-curie-fellowship-programme>
and Information for applicants | IAEA
<https://www.iaea.org/about/overview/gender-at-the-iaea/iaea-marie-sklodowska-curie-fellowship-programme/Information-for-applicants>.
This year IAEA aims to select 150 students.



The IAEA Marie Sklodowska-Curie Fellowship Programme (MSCFP) was launched
in 2020 by the IAEA Director General in an effort to increase the number of
women in the nuclear field, supporting an inclusive workforce of men and
women who contribute to and drive global scientific and technological
innovation. The Programme aims to inspire and encourage young women to
pursue a career in nuclear related fields, by providing highly motivated
female students with scholarships for Master’s programmes and an
opportunity to pursue an internship facilitated by the IAEA.  Scholarships
are awarded annually, to 100+ female students, subject to availability of
funds. In the selection of students, consideration is given to geographic
and field of study diversity, in addition to eligibility requirements and
other criteria. The selected students are awarded up to €20,000 for tuition
costs and up to €20,000 for living costs for their Master’s programme. Upon
completion of their studies, students are also given an opportunity to
pursue an internship for up to 12 months at the IAEA, its partner
organizations as well as industry.  Additionally, students are provided
with opportunities to attend and participate in various educational,
professional and networking  events.  *Since its launch in 2020, MSCFP has
received 1042 applications, selecting 210 students from 93 Member States
studying in 53 countries worldwide.*  The programme is envisaged to grow
each year to ensure more women have an opportunity to pursue advanced
education in nuclear related fields.



*To encourage broad dissemination of the information, we would greatly
appreciate if this communication can be shared within your network and
among relevant organizations, associations and female students pursuing
Master’s degree in nuclear related fields. *



For more information visit: Meet the Marie Sklodowska-Curie Fellowship
Programme students | IAEA
<https://www.iaea.org/about/overview/gender-at-the-iaea/meet-the-mscfp-students>
and Watch Marie Curie Fellowship Programme
<https://eur01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fwatch%3Fv%3DDf5VQtluooA%26list%3DPLCsYX9QVCDTEirWGcjgDrwzN_FRed-O-f%26index%3D10&data=05%7C01%7CT.Beridze%40iaea.org%7C029cc68d2c4044a8bfc908da64d1fc76%7Ca2f21493a4d14b7fad07819c824f5c4a%7C0%7C0%7C637933150586911876%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=gge9ANZ0SUYn1NwON5ipfi2YgRxv7NUc9tMU5KcPjVc%3D&reserved=0>





Thank you



Kind Regards



<https://www.iaea.org/about/overview/gender-at-the-iaea/iaea-marie-sklodowska-curie-fellowship-programme>

<mscfp@iaea.org>*. *

> Hey everyone,
>
> We are glad to inform you that the TRC ROBOT FLEET is currently under
> development. The robots that will be developed in phase 1 are as follows:
> 1. Turtle Bot Waffle Pi
> 2. Turtle Bot Burger
> 3. TRC Robot Mascot
>
> For the same, the club is recruiting for the following positions:
> 1. Position: Designer
>     Requirement: 3D CAD Modelling, 3D printing, Knowledge of mechanisms
> 2. Position: Robot Programmer
>     Requirement: Proficiency in Linux, python and C++, strong
> understanding of OOPs (knowledge of ROS is a plus)
> 3. Position: Hardware Expert
>     Requirement: Knowledge and experience using sensors, motors, drivers,
> and microcontrollers (knowledge of ROS is a plus)
> 4. Position: Computer Vision Expert:
>     Requirement: Knowledge and experience working with various CV models.
> 5. Position: Machine Learning expert
>      Requirement: Knowledge and experience working with various ML models.
> (Knowledge of NLP is a plus).
>
> Computer vision expert and machine learning expert positions are exclusive
> to the TRC Robot Mascot project. The other positions are common to all the
> projects.
> Anyone who is willing to dedicate time and has the required skills is
> welcome to apply irrespective of their program and year of study.
>
> Interested people can fill out this form
> <https://forms.gle/wzj3Gr17N5cTotRB7> by 31st May.
>
> More robots will be added to our fleet in the near future so keep an eye
> out for us!
>
> --
> Best wishes,
> Raj Surya
> Head, The Robotics Club

*****************************************************

Hey everyone,

We are glad to inform you that the TRC ROBOT FLEET is currently under
development. The robots that will be developed in phase 1 are as follows:
1. Turtle Bot Waffle Pi
2. Turtle Bot Burger
3. TRC Robot Mascot

For the same, the club is recruiting for the following positions:
1. Position: Designer
    Requirement: 3D CAD Modelling, 3D printing, Knowledge of mechanisms
2. Position: Robot Programmer
    Requirement: Proficiency in Linux, python and C++, strong understanding
of OOPs (knowledge of ROS is a plus)
3. Position: Hardware Expert
    Requirement: Knowledge and experience using sensors, motors, drivers,
and microcontrollers (knowledge of ROS is a plus)
4. Position: Computer Vision Expert:
    Requirement: Knowledge and experience working with various CV models.
5. Position: Machine Learning expert
     Requirement: Knowledge and experience working with various ML models.
(Knowledge of NLP is a plus).

Computer vision expert and machine learning expert positions are exclusive
to the TRC Robot Mascot project. The other positions are common to all the
projects.
Anyone who is willing to dedicate time and has the required skills is
welcome to apply irrespective of their program and year of study.

Interested people can fill out this form
<https://forms.gle/wzj3Gr17N5cTotRB7> by 31st May.

More robots will be added to our fleet in the near future so keep an eye
out for us!

-- 
Best wishes,
Raj Surya
Head, The Robotics Club

Dear all,
Greetings!

I'm glad to announce that the Garba Night is finally around the corner. I
highly recommend you to wear traditional clothes on the day of the event.

The event is from 5 pm to 7 pm on 30th September . The venue for the same
is Nila Football Ground. Students at Ahalia are advised to board the 4 PM
bus to Nila and after the event 2 buses will leave from Nila to Ahalia at
7.15 PM. I highly recommend you to wear traditional clothes on the day of
the event. Dandiyas have been arranged for the event.

Please find more details about in the poster attached below. Looking
forward to seeing you all there!

*****************************************************

*Use the phrasal words, in the right tense, to fill in the blanks
appropriately*

(a)Sign off: Log off; to stop using a computer, radio, etc., especially to
stop talking on a radio programme
(b) Sign in: Sign one’s name as an indication that one is entering some
location, or on a computer, logging in to a page/site
(c) Sign out: Sign one’s name as an indication that one is leaving some
location, or on a computer, logging off a page/site
(d) Sign up: Add one’s own name to the list of people who are participating
in something
(e) Sign up: Agree to purchase some good or service
(f) Sing along: Sing some music while someone else is singing, or to music

1.  A couple of students came into the cyber cafe yesterday, and did not
................... the computer they used.

2. I don't think Divya meant to ................................... for
organising committee president, if it meant all her weekends would be
sacrificed.

3. The music teacher sang each line of the song she composed and got
students to ......................................

4. Her favorite RJ on Radio Mirchi always ...............................
with an inspirational message

5. Whenever we need volunteers to .................................. for
anything, Shaji is the first person to

6. We were asked to ..............................by 5pm yesterday to
express interest in the excursion

7. It was commonly required in offices that people
............................................ and
............................................., but since Covid even shops
and establishments require that everyone entering the premises
............................................. and
.........................................

8. Anu did ............................... for aerobics and zumba.
Unfortunately not enough people did, and so classes won't be offered

9. I wonder if Karaoke Clubs are popular in Goa, where people
can............................. to recorded background music.

*Answer Key*
1- a, 2-d, 3-f, 4- a (signs off), 5-d, 6-d, 7 -b,c,b,c, 8-e, 9-f

regards, Sandhya

English Language Support & Services
IIT Palakkad
https://iitpkd.ac.in/elss

Dear All,

*Greetings from the Career Development Center, IIT Palakkad.*

The Online Placement training program has been scheduled for the dates 30
and 31 July and 06 and 07 August 2022 by an external training institute
*Six Phrase.*

Please find the schedule attached for the same.

The registered students are divided into 3 batches, the batch wise student
list also attached herewith. Please make sure that you belong to any one of
the 3 batches.

The Online Placement Training program will be via *Google Meet.* The URL
for all 3 batches is given below.


*Batch 1 (60 Students)* :
*http://meet.google.com/kgo-ahjb-sbx <http://meet.google.com/kgo-ahjb-sbx>*

*Batch 2 (61 **Students**) *: *http://meet.google.com/ymk-xzkk-ndo
<http://meet.google.com/ymk-xzkk-ndo>*


*Batch 3 (61 **Students**) *: *http://meet.google.com/zth-dxcz-bow
<http://meet.google.com/zth-dxcz-bow>*


*Note :The above google meet link is the master link for all the  4
sessions scheduled for all the 4 days. Please do join in the respective
batch google meet link only.*


All the students should join the Telegram Group
<https://t.me/+M0oPE6WU1hwyOTE1> of *Six Phrase* for training related
activities, updates, and student queries regarding login etc.

*Telegram Link : https://t.me/+M0oPE6WU1hwyOTE1
<https://t.me/+M0oPE6WU1hwyOTE1>*

DAY 255
26/06/2022

*PAY IT FORWARD *


Reflect on the people in your life who make you feel loved and supported.
In what ways do they do this? How can you “pay it forward” by offering
those same gifts to them and others?

FORWARD TOGETHER

On Thu, 6 Oct 2022, 15:17 Training and Placement Officer IIT Palakkad, <

Dear Sir/Madam,



Greetings of the Day!



To foster and inculcate the translational research and deep-tech
innovations in interdisciplinary cyber-physical systems (ICPS) with a
central theme on Speech, Text and Video Analytics, IIT Patna Vishlesan
i-Hub foundation invites applications for Chanakya UG/PG fellowships.


We, IIT Patna Vishlesan I Hub Foundation(https://tih.iitp.ac.in/index.php)
 are looking for young engineering students for our UG and PG Fellowships.


Request you to kindly circulate the details and google form for filling and
further application process.


Link : https://forms.gle/PaKBThQEAhTa4ADm6



Looking forward to hearing from you.



Thanking you

Warm Regards

Jawar Singh

                                    <table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0">
                                        <tbody>
                                            <tr>
                                                <td>
                                                    <div class="canceled">
                                                        <p
                                                            style="margin: 0 0 25px; font-size: 16px; color: #101010; line-height: 22px;">
                                                            Hi Joel Sam Mathew,
                                                        </p>

                                                        <div class="text_box"
                                                            style="margin: 0; font-size: 16px; color: #101010; line-height: 24px;">
                                                            <p>This is a gentle reminder to attempt the quiz round of Flipkart GRiD 4.0 - Software Development Challenge.</p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Kindly read through the following key instructions regarding the structure, timeline, and rules: </span><strong>Timelines & Questions: </strong></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><strong>Online Quiz Window: 1st July 2022 from 12:00 PM IST (6:30 am GMT) </strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">to </span><strong>2nd July 2022 8:00 PM IST (2:30 PM GMT)</strong></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><strong>Online Quiz Duration: </strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">30 Minutes </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><strong>Total Questions to be answered: </strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">30 Questions </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><strong>Time Per Question:</strong><span style="font-weight: 400;"> 60 seconds</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The questions will be based on </span><strong>e-commerce trivia, tech awareness </strong><strong>and computer science fundamentals</strong></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">All the members of the team are eligible to appear for the quiz round. The final marks will be rewarded based on the </span><strong>average score of the team members attempting the quiz </strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">(For ex - in a team of 3, if all the 3 members attempt the quiz and score 3,4 & 5 marks respectively, the team score will be [(3+4+5)/3] which equals 4)</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You can attempt the quiz anytime between the provided quiz window</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Please ensure that you attempt the quiz in one sitting, as once you start the quiz, the timer won’t stop</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You will have to finish the quiz before </span><strong>2nd July 2022 08:00 PM IST (2:30 PM GMT)</strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">. To get the complete assessment duration, you need to start the assessment latest by </span><strong>2nd July 07:30 PM IST (2:00 PM GMT). </strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">Otherwise, you’ll get less time to complete the assessment</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You can take the assessment only on a desktop/laptop with webcam access</span></li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Proctoring Related: </strong></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> You can play the quiz only on a </span><strong>desktop/laptop with webcam access</strong></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><strong> The quiz will be hosted in full-screen mode</strong></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anything that disturbs the full-screen mode of the assessment is treated as a violation. It may be due to any of the following reasons but not limited to: </span></li>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Tab Switching </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Screen Sharing with anyone </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Clicking on the escape button </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Computer going on Sleep (Adjust your power or sleep mode settings)</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Windows or Browser or any Application specific notifications (Put them No Disturb Mode or switch them off while the assessment is on)</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anything else that may result in disturbing the full-screen mode </span></li>
</ul>
</ul>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The assessment doesn’t get terminated on the first such instance. Only repeated violations will result in disqualification and termination of the assessment immediately. Your face will be verified before the start of the assessment from the photo that was captured during registration. </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your face may be verified again during the assessment</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your face will be constantly detected and violations will be tracked while the assessment is on. Violations might be </span></li>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Two-faced in front of the camera, </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The different person taking the assessment than the one who registered</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">No one in front of the camera </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">And many more such violations are tracked and reported </span></li>
</ul>
</ul>
<p><strong>Key Instructions: </strong></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You can access the quiz from the </span><a href="https://unstop.com/hackathon/flipkart-grid-40-software-development-challenge-flipkart-grid-40-flipkart-348170?refId=MLwJx0Y4"><span style="font-weight: 400;">opportunity page</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> itself where you registered</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You'll see </span><strong>a button </strong><span style="font-weight: 400;">in the respective round if you've registered to initiate the quiz</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You'll have to submit answers to all the questions </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">While you are taking the assessment, your answers and the time of their submission are also tracked by the system question-wise </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You will be able to browse through the questions </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You'll be able to modify your answers before finally submitting your answers</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">There is no negative marking for this quiz </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Any participant resorting to unfair practices will be directly disqualified from the challenge </span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">All decisions in the matter of eligibility, authenticity & final judgment will be with Unstop and Flipkart </span></li>
</ul>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">All the best! </span></p>
<p><strong>Regards, </strong></p>
<p><strong>Team Flipkart</strong></p>
                                                        </div>

*****************************************************

Dear Students,

IIT Delhi is conducting a Winter School on Theoretical CS this December.
This is going to be a good workshop. So if Theoretical CS is your calling,
then don't miss registering.

Regards
Deepak

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Nikhil Balaji <nbalaji@cse.iitd.ac.in>
Date: Fri, 14 Oct 2022 at 09:01
Subject: IIT Delhi Winter School on Theoretical Computer Science (Dec 5-9)
To: <deepak@iitpkd.ac.in>, <kdinesh@iitpkd.ac.in>, <krithika@iitpkd.ac.in>,
<rvarma@iitpkd.ac.in>
Cc: <cstheory.iitd@gmail.com>


Dear Deepak, Dinesh, Kritika, Rohith,

The Department of Computer Science and Engineering at IIT Delhi
is organising a winter school on theoretical computer science from December
5-9*, *2022. https://cstheory.iitd.ac.in/winter-school/index.html

The winter school will have lectures by IITD faculty members on topics
ranging from algorithms, computational social choice, quantum computing,
complexity theory and more.  There will also be informal interaction
sessions with the faculty members, *and* graduate students as well as a
Delhi excursion trip and a farewell dinner.


We invite applications from pre-final and final year undergraduate and
Masters students in computer science, mathematics and related areas.
Applications should be submitted online *latest by 25 October 2022 *at the
following link:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSf39Gq-VRGBe3SSPNISGd4OnA06XUb9OnReZNIhoSJN6Z1XAA/viewform
Students from historically underrepresented groups, differently-abled
students, and women students are especially encouraged to apply. The
details of the selected applicants will be communicated by email by *7th
November*.


Could you please help us advertise the event by forwarding this email on
the relevant mailing lists at your own and other departments? Additionally,
could you please display a printed copy of the attached poster at your
department notice board? If needed, we will be happy to send you a poster
by post, so please let us know. For any further queries, please feel free
to reach out to cstheory.iitd@gmail.com.


Best wishes,

Nikhil Balaji
Assistant Professor,
Department of Computer Science and Engineering,
Indian Institute of Technology Delhi,
Hauz Khas, New Delhi
Delhi 110016
Email: nbalaji@cse.iitd.ac.in
Web: https://sites.google.com/view/nikhilbalaji/home


-- 
Deepak Rajendraprasad
Department of Computer Science and Engineering
Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad


*****************************************************

--
Prof. Dr. Jagadeesh Bayry,
Dean (Student Affairs),
Indian Institute of Technology Palakkad
Sikharam block, Nila Campus.
